Confessionally Reformed Theology

Johannes Hoornbeek (c. 1666) on the Last Things

[Institutiones Theologicae Ex Optimis Autoribus Concinatae (ex officinâ Francisci Moyardi, 1658)]

  • II. As man consists of two essential parts, soul and body, so when he dies, his soul remains ever immortal.
  • III. Separated from the body after death, souls in this state subsist, live, and are wholly touched with their own sense.
  • Objection. But it is objected against our position that it is said in Hebrews 11 that the fathers did not receive the promise, since God had provided something better for us, that they might not be perfected without us. Therefore, someone may say, since eternal life was promised to them, they did not receive it, and will not receive it without us.
  • IV. And souls act in the place either of the heavenly abode of the blessed or the infernal abode of the damned, according to the manner of life previously lived, whether well or ill.
  • V. The Limbus and Purgatory of the Papists are nothing.

  • Objection. It is said of Jacob and others in Genesis 37:35, “I will go down to him into hell.” So elsewhere.
  • Objection. But he thought his son was torn by wild beasts; therefore, he does not speak of the grave but of hell.
  • Objection. Hebrews 11:39, “These all died, not having received the promise, because God had provided some better thing for us, that they without us should not be made perfect.”
  • Objection. Hebrews 9:8, “The Holy Spirit signifying that the way into the holy place was not yet made manifest, while the first tabernacle was yet standing.”
  • Objection. But it is better referred to the way and its opening to the heavenly sanctuary.
  • VI. Therefore, we deem that prayers should no longer be offered for the dead.
  • VII. Even the souls of the saints in heaven enjoy the vision of God.
  • Objection. Various places are objected where the reward is promised to the faithful after the last judgment, as Matthew 25:1; 2 Corinthians 10; 2 Timothy 4:8.
  • VIII. But they are not affected with particular care for those dwelling on earth, so as to come from heaven to aid them.
  • Objection. The example of Samuel in 1 Samuel 28:16, who, called up by the witch, announced Saul’s fate.
  • IX. It is an error to hold that Christ, a thousand years before the universal judgment, will establish a kingdom in the world in which the godly and martyrs, raised from the dead, will reign, with the enemies of the Church defeated, and meanwhile enjoy the highest earthly peace and felicity.
  • I. And first, whether Christ, before or at the beginning of these thousand years, leaving heaven, will come to earth and among His own, both converted Jews and others, establish a certain earthly kingdom like other princes?
  • Question. It is therefore asked, what is the meaning of this place?
  • II. It remains concerning all the godly, without respect to either martyrs or the Jews’ dwelling in the land of Canaan: Whether Christ will establish such a kingdom of the Church in this world before the end of the world, which will be external, and such that all the godly alone will constitute the Church, and subdue all other nations to themselves, and that in a certain place in the world, whether in Judea or elsewhere?
  • X. At the end of the world, Christ will come from heaven in the clouds.
  • XI. Of the Future Resurrection of All Men from the Dead
  • XII. All Men Shall Rise, Even the Wicked.
  • XIII. And All Shall Rise in the Same Bodies.
  • XIV. But Those Found Alive on the Last Day, as They Shall Not Properly Die, So Neither Shall They Rise, but Shall Undergo Something Analogous, That Is, They Shall Be Changed.
  • XV. Christ Shall Judge All.
  • XVI. The Parts of the Judgment Are the Pronouncement of Sentence and Its Execution.
  • XVII. The Time and Place of the Judgment, as Regards Those to Be Judged, Are Equally Uncertain.
  • XVIII. Now Also This World Shall Perish, Not by Total Annihilation, but by Transformation for the Better.
  • XIX. The Blessed Shall Be Taken Up into the Heavens, Perfectly and Eternally Glorified in Body and Soul.
  • XX. But Heavenly Blessedness Consisteth in the Enjoyment or Vision of Divine Glory.
  • XXI. But the Damned Shall Be Cast into Hell, to Be Punished Eternally.
  • XXII. Concerning the Place and Fire of Hell, We Ought Not to Be Curiously Solicitous, but Only to Take Heed Diligently and Timely to Avoid It.
  • XXIII. Lastly, That There Shall Be Degrees of Glory and of Punishments in the Life to Come Is Not Improbable.
  • Objection. One place, Matthew 20:12, where all who labor in the vineyard receive equal reward. But this is spoken with respect to those who labored not equally long.
  • Second Objection. There shall be no cause why more should be given to one than to another, for it is of Christ’s merit and grace.

CHAPTER XVI. CONCERNING THE LAST THINGS

I. Thus far we have beheld those things which befall man in this life, according to the state of the Church militant. Now we proceed to the end, contemplating the Church triumphant, from death, at Christ’s coming, in the resurrection, the judgment, and eternal life.

PROFESSOR. Whatsoever is done by man or concerning man is concluded within two bounds, which the ancient theologians, not departing from the words of Scripture (Proverbs 2:20; 4:26, 27; Matthew 7:13; 2 Corinthians 7:7; Hebrews 4:14), signified by the names of the way and the homeland. To these corresponds the distinction of the Church into militant and triumphant. Those matters hitherto disputed pertained to the way and the state of the Church militant on earth; those hereafter to be examined pertain to the homeland and the goal, or to the state of the Church triumphant in heaven, and the full overthrow, subjection, and consignment of its enemies to the eternal torments of hell. Of this most final and most diverse state of the godly and the ungodly, the necessary antecedents are the resurrection of the dead and the last judgment. For it is appointed unto man once to die, and after this the judgment (Hebrews 9:27). But there can be no judgment of the dead so long as they are dead, for they must appear in judgment. That this may be, the resurrection of the dead must precede.

SPANHEMIUS. The benefits of justification and sanctification are followed by the benefit of glorification, whereof the former holds the place of cause, the latter of the way; each being effects of election unto life, certainly following thereupon, according to Romans 8:29-30; 1 Corinthians 1:30. This benefit of glorification can be considered with respect to the sons of God: I. Antecedently, II. Formally. Antecedently, in the resurrection of the flesh and the judgment; formally, in the perfected blessedness of the sons of God.

II. As man consists of two essential parts, soul and body, so when he dies, his soul remains ever immortal.

JUNIUS. Whether the soul alone is man, so that the body is to it as a ship to a sailor or a horse to a rider, since these are said to be mutually affected, or whether the body alone bears some relation to the soul, as a cup or vessel to a potion, fitted to contain the potion, we deem it frivolous to inquire. But that man consists of soul and body, so that neither the soul alone nor the body alone, but both together constitute man, whose essential parts are soul and body, Holy Scripture teaches with sufficient clarity. The same was also held by the ancient Academics, as Varro attests, citing Antiochus of Ascalon, the teacher of Cicero and Lucullus, and also by the Peripatetics and philosophers of better repute, such as Aristotle (Augustine, City of God, Book 19; Aristotle, On the Soul, Book 1). Indeed, common sense and experience teach that every animal which receives life is likewise subject to death; but that men remain after death, awaiting judgment, Paul teaches (Hebrews 9:27). In that intermediate time, wherein any soul is preserved to be restored to its former body, whether briefly or at length, according as each departs this life sooner or later, its essence nonetheless persists incorruptibly, as is sufficiently demonstrated throughout the sacred writings. That the nations believed in the immortality of the soul, their monuments sufficiently declare (Aristotle, On the Soul, Book 3, Text 20; Pherecydes, Phocylides, Hermippus in Pemand., Chapter 10; Epicharmus in Clement; Cicero, Tusculan Disputations, Book 1, and Consolation, also On the Nature of the Gods, Book 2, and On Laws, Book 1; Maccabees). Scripture clearly teaches that souls survive death, and from innumerable places, these two shall suffice for us: Ecclesiastes 12:7; Matthew 10:28.

III. Separated from the body after death, souls in this state subsist, live, and are wholly touched with their own sense.

JUNIUS. We say that the condition of souls after death is not a state of idleness or slumber, or anything similar, for to imagine it as lifeless would be absurd, since, as Tertullian testifies (On the Flesh of Christ, Chapter 4), the sense of the soul is its very life, and its proper nature is to be awake, to move, to understand, and so forth. Rather, it is a certain condition enduring forever, either of sorrow, namely for the damned, whom the Lord has not deemed worthy in this life of the spirit of regeneration or the grace of perseverance; or of joy, for those who, according to God’s decree, are called in Christ, whereby they live as partakers of free and ineffable glory with God, and their bodies shall one day become like His most glorious body. For the soul’s condition can be considered in three ways: I. As it is united to the body in nature. II. As it is separated from the body after death. III. As it will be after the resurrection, restored to its body. 

MACCOVIUS. The Socinians first deny that human souls survive death, as is evident from Socinus in his Response to the Defense of Francis Pucci, Chapter 1, near the end, where he addresses the words of Ecclesiastes 12:7, “The spirit returns to God who gave it.” Socinus says, “Nothing prevents speaking of something that does not subsist; for God has given us many things that do not subsist by themselves: strength, good health, intellect, skill, and the like. But among other things (which He bestows on all), this animal life, or rather the power of living, which is called both spirit and soul.” From this it is clear that they hold the soul to be an accident, for Socinus says it does not subsist by itself and is of the same kind as intellect, sagacity, or the faculty of sight. But according to Socinus, all these argue that the soul is an accident. Yet when the subject is destroyed, the accident is destroyed, for the essence of an accident is to inhere; therefore, when man dies, the soul does not survive. That this opinion is false is shown by many things; we shall touch on a few. Matthew 10:28: “Fear not them which kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul.” This passage cannot stand according to Socinus’s opinion; for if the soul is not a subsisting thing, that is, if it is an accident, those who kill the body destroy it at the same time, for upon the corruption of the subject, all accidents are corrupted, as has been said. Secondly, Ecclesiastes 12:7 demonstrates the same: “Before the dust returns to the earth as it was, and the spirit returns to God who gave it.” If it returns to God at death, then it is subsisting. Socinus opposes this in his Response to the Defense of Francis Pucci, Chapter 1, near the end, saying that to affirm that the souls of the wicked, subsisting by themselves, return to God at death is impious, and that this impiety exceeds that which they attribute to his words, as those who are truly godly and know from God’s Word that only innocence and piety open the way to heaven will judge. This is ineptly said by Socinus. For this return is understood with respect to the wicked, not to the abodes of the blessed, but to God as Judge, who, according to their deeds in the body, will adjudge the spirit either to the abyss of hell or to the upper room of the godly. But indeed, Scripture testifies not only that the soul of the godly cannot be killed when the body is slain, and that it returns to God at death, but also that it is in heaven, as in Colossians 1:20, where it is read that God, through the blood of Christ’s cross, has reconciled all things to Himself through Christ, both those on earth and those in heaven. But He could not have reconciled any in heaven except the faithful departed, who died before Christ’s ascension. Therefore, the faithful were in heaven before Christ’s ascension. For the blessed angels had not fallen from God’s grace, nor were they at enmity with God, so as to need reconciliation. The angels who fell were not in heaven, nor can they be reconciled, for their destruction is certain, as said in the Epistle of Jude. Therefore, since the Apostle teaches that through Christ’s blood He reconciled to Himself the whole Church, both in heaven and on earth, it is necessary that there were some in heaven before Christ’s death who were reconciled to God through Christ’s blood, since Christ is the Lamb slain from the foundation of the world. Thus, the holy elect, believing in Him who was to come, were saved just as we are saved, who believe in Him now manifested. Let us proceed: The Socinians therefore deny that the soul separated from the body lives; thus Smalcius, in his Disputation on the Last Judgment against Franz, page 409, says that just as the body without the spirit is a corpse, so conversely the spirit without the body can perform no actions. Hence, they affirm that the spirit after the body’s death is endowed with no sense, as Socinus asserts. What can be concluded from this but that the Socinians deny the immortality of the soul? Yet how vain all this is evident from the fact that Paul, in 2 Corinthians 12:3, testifies that in his rapture he heard ineffable words which it is not lawful for a man to utter. Yet he doubted whether he was out of the body or in the body (verses 2-3). For if the soul perceives nothing outside the body, no cause for doubt would have remained for Paul to judge himself rapt out of the body. Indeed, that souls separated from the body live is further evident from Matthew 22:32 and Luke 20:38. Moreover, this also shows that souls not only survive death but live, for Moses, though dead, was seen speaking with Christ (Matthew 17:2). They also deny that the souls of the faithful enjoy happiness before Christ’s coming. For thus Smalcius, in Against Franz, page 409, says: “Whether that spirit which returns to God and is separated from the body is endowed with any sense, or enjoys any pleasure before Christ’s coming and before the new conjunction of the spirit with the glorified body, we greatly doubt; indeed, we believe it to be otherwise.” But this opinion is refuted, both by other places in Scripture and by Revelation 14:13: “Blessed are they who die in the Lord.” Those who die in the Lord are those who, united and joined to Christ through faith, grow together as it were into one body. Just as not only those who believed after Christ’s ascension grew into one body, but also those who preceded Christ’s day. Thus, the Apostle, speaking of the blessed resurrection, in 1 Thessalonians 4:16, says that Christ will descend from heaven with the voice of the archangel, and those who died in Christ will rise first. Here the Apostle calls all the faithful “dead in Christ”; therefore, all the faithful, elect, and holy of God are pronounced blessed, and blessed from that moment, immediately from the time of death. But how are they blessed? Certainly, as the Holy Spirit testifies, that they rest from their labors, and their works accompany them. “Works” is used metonymically for the reward and prizes of works, as it is said in 2 Corinthians 5:10: “We must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, that every one may receive the things done in his body, according to that he hath done, whether it be good or bad,” that is, the rewards of what he has done, according to what he has done, whether good or bad. See on this matter Galatians 6:7 and following. But perhaps “ἀκολουθεῖ μετ’ αὐτῶν” should not be translated “accompany” but “follow.” Sometimes, if they follow, they follow from afar, as Peter followed Christ from afar because of fear (Matthew 26:58). But by this change of phrase, it seems to signify more, namely, to follow in such a way as to walk together, that is, to accompany. Now, where is this reward, which accompanies, rendered? In heaven. Thus we read in Matthew 4:11-12. Therefore, the reward of all the elect accompanies them, that they may be blessed from that moment; but the reward of the faithful is in heaven. Therefore, the souls of all the faithful are received into heaven immediately at death. Thus, the Socinian opinion is refuted.

Objection. But it is objected against our position that it is said in Hebrews 11 that the fathers did not receive the promise, since God had provided something better for us, that they might not be perfected without us. Therefore, someone may say, since eternal life was promised to them, they did not receive it, and will not receive it without us.

Response. I. The Socinians cannot use this argument, for they deny that eternal life was promised to the fathers in the Old Testament. II. It is said they did not receive the promise in this life. Therefore, it concerns a promise to be fulfilled in this life, and that promise can be none other than the manifestation of Christ and the full revelation of the mystery of our redemption. For I do not think anyone will deny that they obtained the remission of sins and the Holy Spirit according to the economy then in force. Then, in the same place, it is written that they might not be perfected without us. But this perfection lies in the manifestation of the promise, for they were not perfected because they had not attained the promise. We, therefore, are perfected before them, for we have attained the promise; but the promise was of a thing to be performed in this life. Therefore, the difference between our perfection and that of the fathers lies in what is manifested in this life. But it seems to pose some difficulty that the Apostle said, “that they might not be perfected without us.” But there is no difficulty if we consider God’s economy; it was His counsel that the Church should not be perfected immediately, but at a certain time. Thus, when the Apostle writes, “that they might not be perfected without us,” he meant nothing other than that they should not be perfected before our times were reached. And indeed, our redemption was not known even to the blessed angels (much less to the spirits of the fathers) before Christ was manifested, as it was revealed through Christ. Thus, this entire matter lies in knowledge, which is far clearer when the thing is manifested and revealed than when it is yet to be manifested and revealed, as are prophecies and all God’s predictions, which are far more obscure before their fulfillment than after.

IV. And souls act in the place either of the heavenly abode of the blessed or the infernal abode of the damned, according to the manner of life previously lived, whether well or ill.

PROFESSOR. The separated soul remains immortal, nor does it indulge in sleep, destitute of all blessedness or free from all punishment; but according to the varied condition of men, it is either received immediately after death into the abodes of the blessed, where in joy it awaits the restoration of its body, or it is tormented with infernal punishments until, through the resurrection, the body is restored to it for participation in punishment.

BUCANUS. The souls of the godly who die in the Lord are received by Christ into heaven (Luke 23:43; Acts 7:59; Hebrews 12:23). But the souls of the ungodly, departing from their bodies, are cast into the abyss; for just as Lazarus was carried by the ministry of angels into Abraham’s bosom, so the rich man was cast into torments (Luke 16:23). It suffices for us to know that immediately upon departure from the body, the spirit returns to God who gave it (Ecclesiastes 12:7), and after the dissolution or separation of the soul from the body, it is with Christ (Philippians 1:23), in paradise (Luke 23:43), in peace (Wisdom 3:3), in rest (Hebrews 4:11), in consolation (Luke 16:25), in security (Job 11:15), in the hand of God, so that no torment may touch it, and in the glorification of God’s name. Yet because they await the resurrection of their bodies and the fullest enjoyment of all the goods that God has promised to those who love Him, they can be said to be engaged not in perfect and consummate blessedness, but in inchoate blessedness (2 Timothy 4:8; Revelation 6:9). Conversely, 2 Peter 2:9 says that the unjust are punished, either by deprivation of this life or by other punishments, yet are reserved for the day of judgment, for far harsher eternal punishments, to be tormented in both body and soul.

V. The Limbus and Purgatory of the Papists are nothing.

WALAEUS. The Papists hold that the fathers before Christ’s coming were detained in a subterranean Limbus, outside the sight of God, in a place near hell, though afflicted with no pain but comforted with the expectation of the Messiah. Some now hold this place to be for infants who die without baptism, who feel neither pain nor joy, yet are outside God’s sight. They also hold that infants who died without circumcision were in such a place. Therefore, this place is now empty. But to the point: We say that the souls of the faithful before Christ’s resurrection were in heaven itself. This is proved: I. From the common promises to all the faithful, even before Christ’s resurrection, as in Matthew 5:3, “Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven”; verse 8, “Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God”; verse 10, “Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness’ sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven”; verse 12, “Rejoice and be exceeding glad, for great is your reward in heaven; for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you.” These and many similar sayings were spoken by Christ long before His passion, at the beginning of His preaching, and were true from that time, not made true later, nor untrue in the meantime. II. From manifest places concerning the faithful of the Old Testament alone, as in Colossians 1:20, “Through Christ all things are reconciled, both which are on earth and which are in heaven.” These cannot refer to angels, for they were not redeemed by Christ; therefore, they are the spirits of the blessed. Likewise, Hebrews 12:22, “Ye are come unto mount Sion… and to the firstborn enrolled in heaven.” These cannot be angels, for they cannot be called firstborn, and here they are expressly distinguished from angels, or the myriads of angels. III. By examples: Of Enoch it is said that he was translated that he should not see death (Hebrews 11:5), and that he was translated by God; therefore, he was translated into heaven. The example of Elijah, who in 2 Kings 2:11 is expressly said to have been translated into heaven. Likewise, of Moses and Elijah, it is said in Matthew 17:3 that they appeared in glory, and then were received through a cloud, from which came the voice, “This is my beloved Son” (Mark 9:7). They did not, therefore, return to earth, as the Papists would have it. We have also the example of Lazarus, who in Luke 16:22 was carried by angels into Abraham’s bosom. Where is it written that angels carry souls to hell? Furthermore, Abraham’s bosom is that of which Christ says in Matthew 8:11, “I say unto you, that many shall come from the east and west, and shall sit down with Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, in the kingdom of heaven.” Finally, the example of the thief crucified with Christ, to whom it was said, “Today shalt thou be with me in paradise” (Luke 23:43). But paradise is expressly explained by the Apostle Paul in 2 Corinthians 12:2 as the third heaven, when he says he was caught up into paradise, into the third heaven.

Objection. It is objected from 1 Peter 3:19 that Christ by the Spirit preached to the spirits in prison.

Response. Certain ancient fathers, such as Clement and others who followed him, understood this place as referring to the hell of the damned. But that this interpretation is alien to Scripture is proved: Because in this life alone are we invited to repentance. John 9:4, “The hour cometh when no man can work.” Galatians 6:7, “Whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap; while we have time, let us do good unto all men.” 2 Corinthians 5:10. See the example of the rich man (Luke 16:27), “No man can pass from us to you.” II. Beza rightly observed that by “prison” here is meant hell, not Limbus; those in prison were not preached to when they were there, but when Peter wrote the epistle, so that the present participle is to be supplied, not the imperfect, “who are in prison,” not, as the Vulgate translates, “who were in prison.” This is shown both by the opposition τοῖς ἐν φυλακῇ ὄντας and ἀπεθανόντας, and because Christ is said to have preached by His Spirit, whereby He was quickened, that is, by His divinity. III. Because it is said He preached to the disobedient. But the faithful were obedient. As for what is said in 1 Peter 4:6, that the Gospel was preached to the dead, it is to be understood that just as Christ will judge the living and the dead, that is, those already dead and those still living, so the Gospel was preached to the dead when they were living. Augustine, Bede, and others, as cited by Rainolds (On the Apocrypha, page 1045), explain the place, as does Beza, namely, of those who lived in Noah’s time and were disobedient, to whom the Spirit of Christ preached the Gospel through Noah, the preacher of righteousness (1 Peter 1:11), as “τοῖς ἐν Ῥώμῃ” means “those who are in Rome,” “οἱ ἐν σαρκί” means “those who are in the flesh” (Romans 8:8), and “οἱ ἐν Χριστῷ” means “those who are in Christ.” This is a common Greek ellipsis.

Objection. But 1 Peter 4:6 says that the Gospel was preached to the dead, that they might be judged according to men in the flesh, but live according to God in the spirit.

Response. This is the purpose of the preached Gospel, that the flesh be mortified and the spirit revived, as Paul speaks of excommunication in 1 Corinthians 5:5, “To deliver such an one unto Satan for the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit may be saved.”

Objection. It is said of Jacob and others in Genesis 37:35, “I will go down to him into hell.” So elsewhere.

Response. Our divines respond that the word Sheol signifies the grave, as in many places.

Objection. But he thought his son was torn by wild beasts; therefore, he does not speak of the grave but of hell.

Response. The word for grave is not taken so strictly, but refers to the state of bodies after death, as in Isaiah 38:18, “Hell (Sheol) shall not confess thee, neither shall death praise thee,” but “the living, he shall confess thee.” Sheol is opposed to life; as the Latins say, “Nature buries the abandoned,” that is, without a tomb. So Jeremiah 22:19, “He shall be buried with the burial of an ass,” that is, he shall not be covered with earth but returned to the earth. So clearly in Psalm 6:5, “In death there is no remembrance of thee; in hell who shall give thee thanks?” Here the word “hell” cannot be taken for such a Limbus, where, by their own hypothesis, there is some confession of God, but for the state of death and burial. Thus, Jansenius relates, “Who among the dead, existing, shall celebrate thee?”

Objection. Hebrews 11:39, “These all died, not having received the promise, because God had provided some better thing for us, that they without us should not be made perfect.”

Response. Just as in verse 11, by “promise” is meant the thing promised, namely, the land of Canaan, so here it means the thing promised, namely, Christ manifested, who was hoped for by them but not granted or given in reality; as Christ elsewhere says that many kings and prophets desired to see what the apostles saw. But what is added, “that they without us should not be made perfect,” is not to be understood absolutely, but relatively. For in Hebrews 12:23, the spirits of the firstborn are said to be perfected in heaven, using the same word τετελειωμένοι; yet they are perfected with us in a certain manner and measure, for though they were partakers of Christ’s benefits through faith before, they lacked communion with Christ Himself, and from that union with Christ now triumphing in heaven, a degree of glory and consolation was added, as is said of the angels in Ephesians 3:10 and 1 Peter 1:12, “Into which things the angels desire to look.” These are simple and not distorted.

Objection. Hebrews 9:8, “The Holy Spirit signifying that the way into the holy place was not yet made manifest, while the first tabernacle was yet standing.”

Response. The Apostle uses the word φανεροῦσθαι, whence some respond, “not yet known.”

Objection. But it is better referred to the way and its opening to the heavenly sanctuary.

Response. Therefore, Paul’s purpose in this chapter and following is to show, not whether the ancient Israelites entered heaven, but whether the ceremonial rites had this power in themselves, which he denies; for the high priest entered alone once, and none entered after or with him. This power, therefore, he teaches is to be attributed solely to the blood and entry of Christ, of which these were shadows. Just as the abolition of sins is claimed solely for Christ’s blood, yet even the Papists will not deny that the Israelites were partakers of that blood of Christ through faith. See also verse 23.

PROFESSOR. By Purgatory, they mean a certain place where, after death, the souls of the faithful who departed this life either still bound by the guilt of some temporal punishment or by some venial sins are tormented according to the measure of divine justice until, fully purged from such sins, they may attain heavenly blessedness (Gregory of Valentia; Bellarmine, On Purgatory, Book 1, Chapter 1). Passing over, therefore, the controversies debated among the Papists themselves concerning the place of Purgatory—though they confess their Church has defined nothing about it, yet according to the more received opinion, which they deem truer, they think it subterranean and near the hell of the damned; concerning the fire, which most hold to be proper, though some improper; concerning its quality, whether it is true and corporeal, which they assert is the most certain opinion of their theologians; concerning the suffrages of the living for the dead, and the like—we shall consider that substantial and primary notion of the term, as they call it, and examine it by the rule of truth. For they hold this doctrine to be so necessary to belief that Bellarmine judges that whoever denies it shall be tormented in the eternal fire of Gehenna (On Purgatory, Book 2, Chapter 15). And Panigarola did not hesitate to deny God’s existence if Purgatory does not exist (Lecture on Purgatory, held in Turin). But we firmly believe that God exists and steadfastly deny that such a Purgatory exists, nor do we fear the torments of hell on that account; for we know that, apart from Christ’s blood and the grace of the Holy Spirit, which are dispensed to believers in this life through the Word and sacraments, no Purgatory has been instituted by God. And though they wrest some testimonies of Scripture, there have been within their own Papist realm those to whom truth extorted the confession that no single Scripture can be readily adduced to compel even the most obstinate to confess, whether he will or not, that Purgatory exists; and if any could be, it has hitherto eluded the most diligent inquisitors (Roffensis, Against Luther, Article 18). Hence, in France, Peter Cotton, a Jesuit, when he could not persuade the living, sought to move the underworld, and what had eluded the most learned, he attempted to extract with the aid of a demon, to whom, among other questions, he proposed this: “What place in Scripture could evidently prove Purgatory?” He knew, as Peter de Soto ingenuously prefaced in his Instruction of Priests, Lecture 1, On Purgatory, that the Scriptures cited by their doctors are less clear, less effective, and less probative; therefore, they should not be used to prove Purgatory. Likewise, it is neither necessary nor expedient to rely on the authority of the place cited from Matthew 12, “It shall not be forgiven, neither in this world, nor in the world to come,” because it can be answered that it was said by way of exaggeration and hyperbole. Nor does the celebrated authority of 1 Corinthians 3, “Yet so as by fire,” establish that there is such a Purgatory after death, for such fire must be understood as that through which both pass, those who build gold and those who build hay. This reasoning, he says, most effectively argues that Purgatory after death is not proved there; or if it seems to some to be proved, certainly because of the ambiguity, the sense is less evident. Therefore, it should not be relied upon. The place from 2 Maccabees 12, which Bellarmine and Gregory of Valentia place in the forefront, concerning some purgatorial fire or place where souls are burned, has nothing to support it, and can be explained so that suffrages for the dead, at least from Judas’s act, cannot be proved. Moreover, concerning the authority of that book, whether it is canonical, there was doubt among the ancients, which in Augustine’s time had not yet been sufficiently clarified, as de Soto says, asserting that the doctrine of Purgatory is more certain and evident than the authority of that book; nor should less evident things be confirmed by more evident ones. Not only is this doctrine unwritten, but also contrary to Scripture, as we need not show (as some adversaries unjustly demand) by producing a negative statement verbatim from Scripture, “There is no place of Purgatory for souls after death.” It suffices if we demonstrate that this Papist doctrine conflicts in many ways with Scripture and right reason. I. Scripture, between the faithful and the unfaithful, the good and the evil, those entering through the narrow and the broad gate, the children of this world and the children of the devil, the spiritual and the carnal, posits no middle state; but everywhere establishes an immediate opposition between them (Luke 16:8; Matthew 7:13; 25:32; John 5:29; Romans 8:5). Therefore, it did not recognize those middle ones, neither very evil nor very good; with these removed, Purgatory is empty. The same Scripture commends only two lives, and, as Augustine testifies (Tractate 124 on John), the Church knows these to have been divinely preached and commended to it: one in faith, the other in hope; one in the time of pilgrimage, the other in eternal dwelling; one in labor, the other in rest; one in the way, the other in the homeland; one in the work of action, the other in the reward of contemplation. The first, Paul distinctly circumscribes within the bounds of this life (Romans 8:18; 2 Corinthians 5:10), clearly teaching that the things which are seen are temporal, but those which are not seen are eternal (2 Corinthians 4:18). Since the state of souls after this life is invisible, it must be eternal. The Scholastics themselves understand by “wayfarers” only those who still enjoy the use of this life’s light. We know, with the same Apostle, that “if our earthly house of this tabernacle were dissolved, we have a building of God, a house not made with hands, eternal in the heavens,” not temporal in hell (2 Corinthians 5:1). Outside these two orders, says Ephrem (Treatise on the Abodes of the Blessed, Volume 1), there is no other middle order: I speak of one heavenly, the other infernal. And a little later: “To escape Gehenna is itself to enter the kingdom of heaven, just as to fall from it is to enter Gehenna. For Scripture has not taught us three regions.” Certainly, for he who believes has passed from death to life (John 5:24). And from that moment, those who die in the Lord rest from their labors (Revelation 14:13). For it is absurd that Bellarmine and others hold that some die partly in the Lord and partly not in the Lord, as if they said that someone reached the goal yet still wandered outside it. Wherever Scripture sets forth precepts and examples of immortality, it not only instills no fear of torments and punishments in the godly but provides the fullest matter of hope and joy to their souls, which could not be if the godly believing in Christ had to fear the flames of Purgatory after death, differing from the fire of hell only in duration (Isaiah 57:1). Therefore, the dying sought to be dismissed in peace (Luke 2:29), for to those who are faithful unto death, a crown of life is promised, not a punishment of fire prepared (Revelation 2:10). The same, which the Apostle testifies is reserved for all who love Christ’s coming and for himself after the contest of this life (2 Timothy 4:8). If anyone needed satisfactory purgation after death, surely it was the thief converted on the cross, who confessed he received the due reward of his deeds (Luke 23:41), who should have endured purgatorial punishments for many hundreds of years; yet he hears from Christ, “Today shalt thou be with me in paradise.” For what some Papists allege, that his most patient endurance of death and admirable confession could be accounted as just satisfaction (Bellarmine, On Purgatory, Book 1, Chapter 12)—whence some Jesuits call this thief a martyr of Christ—is utterly repugnant to Scripture and right reason, for he who suffers as a murderer, thief, or evildoer certainly does not suffer for Christ (1 Peter 3:15). Nor can it be said that the privileges of a few do not make a rule. For the same promise was made to all the faithful, that they shall not come into judgment but have passed from death to life (John 5:24). Over them, the sun shall not fall, nor any heat; therefore, not the fire of Purgatory (Revelation 7:14). Thus, the soul of Lazarus, as soon as it departed the body, was carried by angels into Abraham’s bosom, where it enjoyed consolation (Luke 16). Therefore, it did not feel the most grievous pangs in Purgatory. In this faith, the dying desired rather to depart from the body and be present with the Lord (2 Corinthians 5:8), to be dissolved and be with Christ (Philippians 1:23), knowing that the Lord willed that those whom the Father gave Him should be where He is, with Him, not suffering a similar fire near the damned in hell for many years. The time of this present life is the time of sowing; after this life is the time of harvest (Galatians 6:7). Now is the accepted time, the day of salvation (2 Corinthians 6:2). The Son of Man forgives sins on earth (Matthew 9:6). And what is forgiven or loosed on earth is forgiven and loosed in heaven (Matthew 16:19). Since, therefore, the remission of sins and salvation are obtained or lost in this life alone, through faith by the ministry of the Word and sacraments, and in heaven the effect of what is done on earth is to be expected, a Purgatory outside the habitable earth and heaven is vainly posited.

VI. Therefore, we deem that prayers should no longer be offered for the dead.

PROFESSOR. It is an inept consequence that all who commended prayers and oblations for the dead, and counted those who denied their utility among heretics, believed in Purgatory. For though it be true that the custom of praying for the dead is ancient, it is nonetheless certain that the ancients had other reasons for deeming it useful. Since even the Greek Church, to this day, retains that custom and yet to this day does not believe in Purgatory, as Alphonsus de Castro says (Against Heresies, Book 8, Title on Indulgences). Therefore, the primary reason they poured forth prayers for the dead arose from that doctrine which the Papists themselves now reckon among errors, namely, that so many and such renowned ancient fathers—Tertullian, Irenaeus, Origen, Chrysostom, Theodoret, Ambrose, Clement of Rome, Bernard—did not assent to this opinion (which, after great inquiry, was defined as a doctrine of faith in the Council of Florence), that the souls of the just enjoy the vision of God before the day of judgment, but handed down a contrary opinion, as Stapleton confesses (On the Authority of Scripture, Book 1, Chapter 2, Section 5). To these, Sixtus Senensis adds Justin Martyr, Lactantius, Victorinus, Prudentius, Arethas, and others (Bibliotheca, Book 6, Annotation 345). It is no wonder, therefore, if in this delay of the resurrection, which Tertullian calls the exile of all souls and the penalty of loss (not of sense, to be sure), they deemed prayers for the dead useful. Since the Papists themselves consider this foundation ruinous, we, who are otherwise taught by Scripture, ought not to imitate a useless rite, injurious even to the saints.

VII. Even the souls of the saints in heaven enjoy the vision of God.

WALAEUS. Calvin seems somewhere to doubt this matter, for the ultimate glory in Scripture seems reserved for the faithful after the last judgment. But to resolve it briefly, Calvin does not deny that they are in heaven, but as it were in the court of heaven, if we may so speak, and are to be admitted into the inner sanctuary only then. We, however, freely concede not only that they are in heaven but also that they enjoy God and His vision. I. Because it has been demonstrated that the fathers, even before Christ’s coming, enjoyed heavenly blessedness, which David teaches is situated solely in the sight of God (Psalm 16:11; 23:4; 84:11). II. Because those departing hence go to dwell with the Lord (2 Corinthians 5:6), and therefore the Apostle desires to be dissolved and be with Christ (Philippians 1:23). And Christ says in John 17:24, “I will that they also be with me where I am.” But dwelling with Christ and being with Christ necessarily implies the vision of God, for He entered into heaven to appear in the presence of God for us (Hebrews 9:24). The throne of the Son is the throne of the Father (Revelation 3:21). III. Paul, in 2 Corinthians 12:2, was caught up into the third heaven and saw Christ and other ineffable things; therefore, much more the faithful departed. Moreover, throughout Revelation, not only the twenty-four elders and angels, but also the elect from every nation, tribe, and tongue, stand before the throne of God and the Lamb, singing praises to Him day and night (Revelation 4:8; 5:8; 7:9). IV. Since it is certain that the saints enjoy eternal and heavenly blessedness, from the places cited before, it is necessary that they have it either through faith or through sight; not through faith, for after death faith ceases, and hope that is seen is not hope; therefore, through sight (1 Corinthians 13:12).

Objection. Various places are objected where the reward is promised to the faithful after the last judgment, as Matthew 25:1; 2 Corinthians 10; 2 Timothy 4:8.

Response. These places speak of the perfect glory and blessedness of soul and body together, as they labored together here; meanwhile, it is not denied that some measure of glory accrues to the soul, and a clearer vision, when God shall be all in all, and the soul’s desire for its body, as in Revelation 6:11, shall be fulfilled.

VIII. But they are not affected with particular care for those dwelling on earth, so as to come from heaven to aid them.

WALAEUS. It remains to examine the question whether the blessed in heaven have care for these lower things, and if they have, what kind? The Papists not only attribute this care to the saints, that in heaven they intercede for us before God, but also that they are appointed over kingdoms and provinces, as their patron saints; indeed, they set them over diseases, peace, war, letters, mechanical and liberal arts, in the same manner as the Gentiles did their gods. They appoint Mary over all heaven, and thus call her the Queen of Heaven, from the origin of the name Miriam, “star of the sea,” for “drop of the sea,” wrongly understood from Jerome’s etymology. For “mar” signifies a drop, not a star; so that they have not only multiplied their saints according to the number of cities, but also of villages and human societies. Hence, they invent marvelous apparitions of saints on earth, hastening to aid men. We judge most of these things superstitious. As for their praying for us, we have treated that matter elsewhere, when we spoke of the invocation of saints. In general, we concede that they pray, or rather desire, that the kingdom of God may come, and that God may fulfill the remaining promises that concern both them and us together, as we see in Revelation 6:9, concerning the souls under the altar. That other care we hold to be fabricated outside Scripture, and it is refuted by the following arguments. I. Because Scripture testifies that the saints enter into rest; therefore, not into that laborious office which they assign to them. Genesis 15:15, “Thou shalt be gathered to thy fathers in peace.” Isaiah 57:1-2, “The righteous perisheth, and no man layeth it to heart… he entereth into peace.” So Luke 2:29, “Now lettest thou thy servant depart in peace.” Revelation 14:13, “They rest from their labors.” How, then, does this rest and peace accord with the laborious duties they attribute to them, not in one province but in many, indeed throughout the whole world? As the Portuguese attribute these duties to their James in Spain, East India, and West India. II. From places where care for lower things is expressly denied them, as Job 7:9, “He that goeth down to hell (Sheol, the grave) shall come up no more, nor shall he return any more to his house, neither shall his place know him any more.” So Job 14:21, “If his children increase, he knoweth not; if they decrease, he regardeth not, only his own flesh is pained in him.” So 2 Samuel 12:23, “He shall not return to me, but I shall go to him.” So Ecclesiastes 9:7, “The living know that they shall die, but the dead know not anything.” And of Josiah, it is said in 2 Kings 22:20 that God will gather him to his fathers in peace, that he may not see all the evil which He would bring upon Israel. See also Isaiah 63:16, “Abraham hath not known us.” III. Where the state of the faithful after death is described to us, it is described as enjoying joy (Matthew 25:34), receiving consolation (Luke 16:25), praising God, giving thanks, serving Him day and night, as seen throughout Revelation. Such burdens as are attributed to angels are not attributed to them in Scripture. Acts 13:36 says that David served God’s counsel in his generation and so fell asleep; therefore, he did not serve in that manner afterward. IV. This cannot in any way consist with their nature. For one who performs these things in diverse and distant places—east, west, south—must not only be omniscient but also present in many places at once, which nature rejects. For angels, the matter is different, as they are complete substances and by their multitude can be present in diverse places; but one saint, such as James, they imagine to be in many places at once.

Objection. The example of Samuel in 1 Samuel 28:16, who, called up by the witch, announced Saul’s fate.

Response. That this was not the true Samuel is demonstrated: I. Because the saints are not in the power of demons or witches. II. Because he ascended from the earth, when it has been proved that the saints of the Old Testament were in heaven. III. Because he falsely asserted that Saul would be with him; whereas Samuel was a godly and blessed man, and Saul was ungodly.

IX. It is an error to hold that Christ, a thousand years before the universal judgment, will establish a kingdom in the world in which the godly and martyrs, raised from the dead, will reign, with the enemies of the Church defeated, and meanwhile enjoy the highest earthly peace and felicity.

WALAEUS. The Chiliasts, in Latin called Millenarians, as Augustine and others term them, derive their name from the number of a thousand years; for they hold that Christ, a thousand years before the final and universal judgment, will establish a certain earthly kingdom for the sake of the godly. In this kingdom, with the Antichrist and all the Church’s enemies defeated, only the godly, joined with the martyrs who will rise before the end of the age, will reign and enjoy profound peace. But their opinions differ, one being far more dangerous and less tolerable to Christians than the other. Some thought this kingdom would be so earthly that the Jews would be restored to their land, and together with the living faithful, would enjoy every kind of bodily delights, imagining among these delights a multitude of wives, perpetual feasts and banquets, carnal games, and the like. Also, the rebuilding of the city of Jerusalem, the restoration of the temple, and the reinstatement of Jewish ceremonies and laws. This opinion, taken from Jewish dreams, began to be urged even among Christians by the heresiarch Cerinthus in the time of the Apostles, as Eusebius testifies (Ecclesiastical History, Book 3, Chapter 25; Book 7, Chapter 24). Setting aside this opinion, another follows, which had many supporters among the ancient fathers, whose author is said to have been Papias, a very ancient writer, reputed by some to be a disciple of the Apostle John, though Baronius rightly observed that this is erroneously reported by some; for he was not a disciple of John the Apostle, but of a certain John the Presbyter, who lived after the Apostle, around the end of Trajan’s reign. This Papias, as Eusebius reports (Ecclesiastical History, Book 3, Chapter 36), was Bishop of Hierapolis, otherwise an upright man, so much so that he is honored among martyrs by the Roman Church, but, as Eusebius testifies, of slender judgment, who, neglecting apostolic writings, diligently followed the traditions of the elders. He visited individuals he knew had conversed with the Apostles to learn what each Apostle had taught, and thus first imbibed this error, deceived by the allegorical modes of speech in John’s Revelation and other prophets, which he thought should be understood literally. From the same foundations, Irenaeus, Justin, Tertullian, Apollinarius, Victorinus, Nepos the Egyptian (who also defended this in a published book), Severus Sulpitius, Lactantius, and others drew this opinion, so that it persisted among most fathers almost until the times of Eusebius, Jerome, and Augustine, who refute it, though they sometimes acknowledge having held it. They hold that the Church will endure six thousand years in the world with labor and affliction, but in the seventh millennium, it will have its Sabbath, and then the kingdom will be given to the godly, the ungodly defeated, and the Church will enjoy peace and an abundance of both spiritual and bodily benefits, though honest ones. Some add that before these thousand years, the Jews will be converted, and the jeweled Jerusalem and the land of Canaan will be inhabited, the martyrs will rise, the Antichrist will be abolished, Christ Himself will descend from heaven and be their King, establishing a monarchy with enemies subdued and Satan bound. After enjoying these pleasures for these thousand years, the universal judgment will follow, and the consummation of the age will ensue. Augustine places this opinion among heresies (Heresy 8, page 15, To Quodvultdeus); so does Philastrius (Heresy 59, page 26). Damasus condemned it in the Roman Synod around the year 373. Yet in our time, it has been revived, first by the Anabaptists in Germany and Westphalia, then by certain Photinians, as Socinus acknowledges in his book Against the Chiliasts; and not many years ago, in part by Piscator and Alsted. Therefore, having well considered all things, I see that this opinion contains various points, which we must treat distinctly. First, that Christ, a thousand years before the last judgment, will be present and establish this kingdom on earth. Second, that before the beginning of this kingdom, either all the godly will be raised, as most ancients thought, or the martyrs alone, with the rest left in death. Third, that they will enjoy an abundance of all spiritual and bodily delights, though lawful, whether in marriage or outside it. Fourth, that the Jews will first be converted and, once converted, restored to the land of Canaan, and so, with Jerusalem rebuilt, will establish a monarchy there, subduing the nations, joining the faithful with them, reducing the unfaithful to the corners and straits of the world, and enjoying profound peace. But after the thousand years, Satan will again be loosed, gathering those remaining nations to battle against the godly, whom Christ will destroy with fire sent from heaven, and thereafter the universal judgment will follow. These are the chief points in this opinion that we must examine.

I. And first, whether Christ, before or at the beginning of these thousand years, leaving heaven, will come to earth and among His own, both converted Jews and others, establish a certain earthly kingdom like other princes?

This the Chiliasts assert from certain places in the Old and New Testaments, especially Revelation 20:4, “They shall reign with Christ a thousand years.” But this opinion is solidly refuted by the following reasons. I. Because nowhere in the New Testament, where the state and condition of Christ’s kingdom are most fully described, is such a coming of Christ mentioned. For the place they cite, Revelation 20:4, does not say they will reign with Christ present on earth; for the faithful can reign with Christ in heaven; indeed, they can reign with Him on earth, though Christ remains in heaven, as it is said in Romans 8:17, “We are joint-heirs with Christ, if we suffer with Him, that we may be glorified with Him.” Just as we are said to suffer with Christ, though Christ is in heaven and we on earth, so we can reign with Christ, though we are on earth and Christ in heaven; and all the faithful are called kings and priests (1 Peter 2:9; Revelation 5:10), and “we shall reign on the earth.” Second, we say this opinion is not only without Scripture but also contrary to Scripture, which I thus show.

I. Because if Christ is to come a thousand years before the end of the age, then the end of the age is known, as Christ testifies (Mark 13:32). Therefore, Peter says in 2 Peter 3:10 that Christ Himself will come as a thief in the night, when He is not expected.

II. Because Christ’s coming is always joined with the last judgment and the general resurrection; therefore, He will not come before that judgment, a thousand years or more. The places of Scripture here are manifest, as 1 Corinthians 15:22; 1 Thessalonians 4:16; Matthew 25:31; 1 John 14:3; 2 Peter 3:3, 10, 15.

III. Scripture testifies that Christ will remain in heaven until the last judgment; therefore, He will not come before to establish a kingdom. John 14:3; Acts 3:21; 1 Corinthians 15:25; Ephesians 1:20; Hebrews 1:3; 8:1; 9:24.

IV.Reason: That which is not necessary for the administration of Christ’s kingdom, indeed, which detracts from the glory and splendor of His kingdom, ought not to be posited. For His kingdom is supercelestial (2 Timothy 4:18; Ephesians 1:20).

V. Reason: Christ is a King in such a way that He is also our Priest; but He will always fulfill His priesthood in heaven through His intercession, as long as there are faithful here who need His intercession (Hebrews 9:24, 27-28; 1 John 2:1).

VI. Reason: Scripture, as well as the Apostles’ Creed, mentions no other coming of Christ than to judge the living and the dead.

Let us now see what is objected to the contrary. The most difficult of all places, and as it were the foundation of this opinion, is Revelation 20:4. But there are many things in that very place that oppose the Chiliasts’ exposition:

I. Because this opinion presupposes that those thousand years, in which the martyrs will rise, are to begin only after the overthrow and complete abolition of the Antichrist, as treated in the preceding chapter. But it is far more probable that he will be overthrown only at the last judgment, as is clear from the end of the preceding chapter, where it is said that the beast and the false prophet will be cast alive into the lake burning with fire and brimstone. Whether these are ever understood otherwise than of the last judgment remains to be proved. Then, 2 Thessalonians 2:8 says that Christ will destroy that son of perdition with the Spirit of His mouth and abolish him with the brightness of His coming, which is usually understood only of Christ’s final coming.

II. This opinion presupposes that this place speaks of what is still to come today, and that no part of it has passed. But that Satan has not hitherto been bound so as not to deceive the nations does not seem true; for Christ is that stronger one who, coming into the house of the strong, bound him and took his goods (Matthew 12:29), and who cast him out of heaven like lightning (Luke 10:18), and who through His death destroyed him who had the power of death (Hebrews 2:14).

Objection. But in that manner, he was not bound so as to deceive no one.

Response. That does not seem necessary, for it concerns a particular deception through the idolatry of the Gentiles, and indeed of entire nations, though afterward he will deceive men in another way until the end of the world, as appears from Matthew 13:24 in the parable of the tares, 1 Peter 5:8, and Ephesians 6:12.

III. It is said in the text that he saw the souls of those who were beheaded. But they say bodies. For what they respond, that John saw, namely by spiritual vision, souls with bodies, is not in the text but in their opinion.

IV. It is said that they lived, not that they lived again; though we do not deny that the word “to live” is sometimes used for “to live again,” and it seems to be so used here from the following words, “This is the first resurrection.” Then, that they reigned with Christ is not said to be on earth, which they all assume. But it can be understood as their spiritual life with Christ in heaven, as also the resurrection.

Objection. And of others, it is said that they did not live again.

Response. Namely, with spiritual life, which is also called resurrection (John 5:29; 12:25; Ephesians 1:20; 3:11), where spiritual life is called life and resurrection.

V. It is said in the text that the rest of the dead did not live again until the thousand years were finished. Therefore, it follows from their opinion, which they urge, that they will rise immediately after those thousand years. But this conflicts with the text, where it is said in verse 7 that Satan will be loosed after the thousand years and will gather the nations to battle against the saints; also, that a thousand years before the last judgment, the time of the last judgment would be known, whereas Scripture testifies that He will come as a thief in the night. It will also follow that no one would be free from the second death except those martyrs, who are said to be blessed who have part in the first resurrection, because the second death has no power over them; whence it follows that they alone will be free from the second death who are free from the first death. For otherwise, this would not be any privilege, and it would bring little consolation to the martyrs if the same happiness pertained to all those who are not partakers of this first resurrection. But it is certain that a peculiar blessedness is described here; indeed, it would be superfluous, for those who are once blessed in heaven easily know that they will be blessed after the resurrection. For what is objected, that the first death cannot be the death of the soul through sin, for otherwise the eternal death would be a third death, since the death of the body intervenes, this is irrelevant, since there are only two spiritual deaths, of sin and of hell; but the death of the body is common to the godly and the ungodly, though with a different end, and therefore is not considered here.

Question. It is therefore asked, what is the meaning of this place?

Response. Ribera, following Augustine, holds that the thousand years are set indefinitely for the whole time from Christ’s birth to the last judgment. But this is refuted, because after the thousand years, it is said that Satan will be loosed; also, at the rise of the Antichrist. But it cannot be that in so short a time, as the Papists imagine, Satan could deceive so many myriads of men, as is here described. Therefore, we concede that a certain time is determined, for both the beginning and the end are set, and the article is four times added, τὰ χίλια ἔτη. Moreover, there are various other interpretations, all of which have their difficulties, but not as great as those of the Chiliasts’ first interpretation. Most orthodox interpreters generally agree that these years have passed; but they do not agree on establishing the beginning. Some interpreters, including Bullinger, Junius, Colladon, and Pareus, begin these thousand years from the destruction of Jerusalem, when the Gospel fully passed to the Gentiles; and therefore, Satan is said to be bound, because his kingdom among the Gentiles was taken away, at which time many martyrs were crowned, because they refused to worship the first beast, that is, pagan Rome, and its image, that is, Antichristian Rome, which after the year 666 began to be such, nor to receive its marks; who therefore are said nonetheless to have lived and reigned with Christ, though the world judged them to have perished or been condemned; and so those thousand years end around the year 1073, about which time the devil, through the Antichrist Gregory VII (Hildebrand) and the Mohammedans, began anew to rage and deceive entire nations to introduce the worship of demons under the guise of saints. Others, however, such as Napier, Taffin, Brightman, and Johannes Gerhard, prefer to begin the thousand years with Constantine, who first closed the Gentile temples and restrained the devil’s violence against the godly, and these end around the year 1300, about which time the Ottoman family began to rage through the world, that is, Gog and Magog. And when the Church began to rise from the darkness of Popery through those witnesses who openly opposed the Antichrist, such as John of Gauduno, Wycliffe, the Waldenses, and others. Blessed, therefore, are those who have part in this resurrection from the errors of the Papists; and they now reign with Christ for another thousand years in the Church, gradually asserting itself more and more, though Satan, then loosed again through the Turk and the Antichrist, opposes them; yet they will grow stronger until, with the beast destroyed and the Turk restrained, a more tranquil kingdom will be granted to the Church, at which time the Jews will also be converted and join the Church. The beginning of the latter thousand years they place in the year 1308; therefore, the rest is still to be expected. That such a state of the martyrs and the godly in the Church is called a resurrection is proved from Revelation 11:11, where the two witnesses, slain, are recalled to life by Christ, not literally in their own persons, but in their successors and other godly pastors; just as John the Baptist came in the spirit of Elijah. This interpretation seems better to resolve the preceding difficulties, except that it interprets all these things allegorically and begins the kingdom of the Antichrist from the times of Constantine, which others consistently reject to the year 666, and from that time the Church fleeing into the wilderness. Be that as it may, we see that other godly doctors offer orthodox expositions that do not contradict the analogy of faith; indeed, even if it were granted that some tranquility for the Church is to be expected after the overthrow of the Antichrist, it would not follow that the martyrs will live here in the world; it suffices if they live and reign with Christ. We therefore leave this matter unresolved.

II. It remains concerning all the godly, without respect to either martyrs or the Jews’ dwelling in the land of Canaan: Whether Christ will establish such a kingdom of the Church in this world before the end of the world, which will be external, and such that all the godly alone will constitute the Church, and subdue all other nations to themselves, and that in a certain place in the world, whether in Judea or elsewhere?

We find no such constitution of the Church before the end of the world in Scripture. This is proved by the following arguments.

I. Because Scripture describes to us such a perpetual state of the Church, in which the godly are mixed with the ungodly, hypocrites with the truly faithful, as is evident from the parable of the tares (Matthew 13), which grow among the wheat until the harvest, that is, the consummation of the world, as Christ there interprets, when the angels, the reapers, will separate the good from the evil. And verse 41, “The Son of man shall send forth his angels, and they shall gather out of his kingdom all things that offend.” Augustine excellently urges this place (City of God, Book 20, Chapter 7). So Christ compares the Church to a net, in which good and bad fish are caught, but the bad are cast out, and the good are kept in vessels: “So shall it be at the end of the world: the angels shall come forth and sever the wicked from among the just” (Matthew 13:49). So also with a great banquet, into which even those not clothed in wedding garments intrude (Matthew 22:11). Likewise with a great house, in which are vessels of gold and clay, for honor and dishonor (2 Timothy 2:20). These express the general state of the Church. The special state near the end of the world, during which they would have the Church enjoy peace, delights, and a kingdom here, is described by these places: Matthew 24:40 and following, “Two shall be in the field; the one shall be taken, and the other left.” And before, verse 11, “Many false prophets shall come and deceive many.” Likewise, Luke 18:8, “When the Son of man cometh, shall he find faith on the earth?”

II. Argument against the second point, whereby they hold that this kingdom is to be established among all the godly in a certain place in the world, where all the godly will dwell together and rule over other nations, is drawn from places in Scripture where the Church of the New Testament is extended throughout the whole world, as Psalm 2:8, “I will give thee the nations for thine inheritance, and the ends of the earth for thy possession.” And Psalm 72:8, “He shall have dominion from sea to sea, and from the river unto the ends of the earth.” So Daniel 2:35; Zechariah 9:10; Revelation 5:9.

III. Argument is drawn from the perpetual condition of the Church militant on earth, which will always be afflicted by Satan, the world, and the flesh, and will bear Christ’s cross, under which state the Church will remain until the consummation of the age, as many places prove; whence it follows that the third mode of this kingdom cannot consist with Scripture, in which the Church and its individual members are always free from such affliction. Let these places be considered: Psalm 34:19, “Many are the afflictions of the righteous.” Matthew 5:4, “Blessed are they that mourn.” Acts 14:22, “We must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of heaven.”

IV. Argument is drawn from places where Christ’s kingdom is described to us as not of this world, nor like other kingdoms of this world. Therefore, Christ’s kingdom is only spiritual here, not worldly and external, and if it is gathered in tranquil kingdoms, then it happens as the Apostle says in Galatians 4:29, that he who is born after the flesh persecutes him who is born after the promise. This is proved from various places, as John 18:36, “My kingdom is not of this world.” And therefore, when the Jews would have made Him a king, He escaped from their midst (John 6:15).

V. Argument: If the reward of the faithful martyrs and all who suffer for Christ is laid up in heaven, then it is not to be sought on earth. The antecedent is true. Therefore, the conclusion follows. The antecedent is proved from Matthew 5:12, “Great is your reward in heaven,” and 19:21, “Thou shalt have treasure in heaven.” 1 Peter 1:4, “An incorruptible crown of glory is reserved for us in heaven.”

X. At the end of the world, Christ will come from heaven in the clouds.

AMES. Christ’s second coming will be like His first in that it will be real, visible, and apparent (Acts 1:11). But it will be unlike in that: I. It will be with the highest glory and power (Matthew 24:30; Titus 2:13). II. It will be with the greatest terror with respect to the wicked, and with the greatest joy for all the godly (2 Thessalonians 1:7-10).

WALAEUS. The time of this coming is not precisely denoted to us in Scripture, though in general, various signs of Christ’s coming to judgment, and thus of the consummation of the age, are set before us, especially in Matthew 24; Mark 13; Luke 21; 2 Thessalonians 2. These signs are nearly all fulfilled, except perhaps the calling of the Jews, of which Romans 11:25 speaks. But of this matter elsewhere. Christ expressly testifies that no one knows that day and hour (Mark 13:32), not even Christ Himself, according to His human nature. Whether He now knows it in heaven is not determined for us, though it is probable, for in Revelation, after His ascension, He opened the book sealed with seven seals (Revelation 5:5), in which were contained the things to come until the end of the age. But men do not know it (Matthew 24:42; Luke 21:35). He says He will come as a thief comes in the night: I. Unexpected by men (1 Thessalonians 5:2). II. As lightning suddenly appears from the east to the west, when men are eating, drinking, secure, as in the days of Noah (Matthew 24:27), and elsewhere passim. Peter, in his second epistle, pursues this at length. Whence it appears that those men are rash who dare to define the day, month, or year of this matter, whoever they may be.

XI. Of the Future Resurrection of All Men from the Dead

MART. It is called by the Greeks ἀνάστασις, in the composition of which word, the preposition ἀνὰ is equivalent to πάλιν, that is, “again,” as if it signified to stand again that which had fallen. Wherefore Damascenus, writing of this matter, saith, ἀνάστασιν δευτέραν ἢνεκρῶν στάσιν, that is, a second rising or standing of the dead. But the Hebrews named it Thechijath. For chaja is to live: wherefore it is as if they said, the vivification of the dead. And since among them com is to rise, from thence they derived the Hebraic name, Thekum Hammethim, that is, the rising of the dead. Also among them is found cuma; and from the verb Amad, which is to stand, they derived some name of this kind. There be perchance other words among them of this signification, but these are more commonly used and frequent among the Rabbins.

BUCAN. Resurrection properly signifieth a certain repeated standing, which the Greeks call ἀνάστασις, as it were a second and fallen standing: for τὸ ἄνα in composition signifieth re and upward: and στάσις is I stand: and in general it is opposed to falling, for he that hath fallen is properly said to rise again. But in particular, it signifieth the return or restitution of bodies from death to life. And it is twofold: universal or final, which none shall escape, reserved for the last day, as Job 14:12, which we confess in the Creed, I believe in the resurrection of the flesh. Particular or precedent, whereof singular examples are extant in the Scriptures, both Old and New Testament. As:

I. The son of the widow of Sarepta, raised by Elijah, 1 Kings 17:22.

II. The son of the woman of Shunem, whom Elisha restored, 2 Kings 4:33.

III. A certain man raised by the touch of Elisha’s bones lying in the sepulchre, 2 Kings 13:21.

IV. The daughter of Jairus, Matthew 9:25.

V. The only son of the widow in Nain, Luke 7:15.

VI. Lazarus of Bethany, John 11.

VII. Christ Himself, Matthew 28:6, which holdeth the chiefest place.

VIII. Certain saints, whose sepulchres (when the rocks were rent at Christ’s death) were opened, yet they came forth from the tombs after Christ’s resurrection, Matthew 27:52-53. Not that they might live again among men to die again, as Lazarus and others, but rather that they might accompany Christ, by whose power they were raised, into eternal life; that there might be certain testimonies of the life-giving power of Christ.

IX. Tabitha of Joppa, at the command of Peter, Acts 9:40.

X. Eutychus, raised by Paul, Acts 20:10.

PROF. That resuscitation which is actively so called from the operation of the efficient cause, is passively called resurrection. This article maketh a distinction betwixt Pagans and Christians, for it is placed beyond the sight of reason, and is a proper voice of the Church, so that Tertullian rightly said, The confidence of Christians is the resurrection of the dead, in his book Of the Resurrection of the Flesh, that what is referred to the Head (Christ) must be referred to all the members: the Pagans and enemies of Christ believe Him to have died; but that Christ is risen, this is the proper faith of Christians. Thus, that all men are subject to death, the Pagans see and grant: but when it cometh to resurrection, it seemeth a ληρώδης λόγος, a foolish word, Acts 17:32. To Pliny, in Book 2 of Natural History, chapter 7, and Book 7, chapter 55, it is a childish delusion. So Caecilius, in Minucius Felix’s Octavius, saith that Christians assert old wives’ tales, claiming they shall be reborn after death, from ashes and cinders, and with some confidence believe their own lies. In one word, if the resurrection of the flesh be denied, it is taken from the school of all Philosophers, Tertullian, On Prescription, chapter 8. Hence the Apostle writeth of the Gentiles in general, concerning the resurrection of the dead, that they are μὴ ἔχοντας ἐλπίδα, without hope, 1 Thessalonians 4:13. And since the patriarchs of heretics were Philosophers, Tertullian, Against Hermogenes, it is no marvel if the Church, from the beginning, suffered contradiction in the doctrine of the resurrection; from the Jews, by the Sadducees, who said there is no resurrection, Matthew 22:23; from Christians, by Hymenaeus and Philetus, teaching that the resurrection is already past, 2 Timothy 2:18, denying the proper resurrection and granting only a figurative one. Among the Corinthians, by many, who are refuted by the Apostle, 1 Corinthians 15:12. Whose heresy was afterward interpolated by the Simonians, Irenaeus, Book 1, chapter 19; Saturnius, Basilides, Carpocrates, Gnostics, Valentinus, Ophites, Cainites, Sethians, Archontics, Serdonians, Marcionites, Lucianus, Apelles, Severus, Origenists, Seleucians, and many others, too tedious to enumerate, of whom Epiphanius in his Panarion, Augustine in On Heresies to Quodvultdeus, Theodoret in On Heretical Fables, Philastrius in On Heresies, and others write. This heresy is also attributed to Pope John XXIII, in the Acts of the Council of Constance, who, persuaded by the devil, pertinaciously believed that the soul of man dieth and is extinguished with the body, like brute beasts, and that the dead, even on the last day, shall in no wise rise again, Session 11, page 106, Quentel edition, 1551, Volume 2. But verily, since the Apostle conjoineth hope and the resurrection of the dead, Acts 24:14, and teacheth that we are of all men most miserable if we hope in Christ only in this life, 1 Corinthians 15:17, that we may hold fast the possession of our hope unwavering, Hebrews 10:23, our mind must be fortified with certain and immovable foundations, whereby our faith and hope in the future resurrection may firmly rest. Wherefore, setting aside certain secondary and probable arguments, and some conveniences or similitudes drawn from nature, which rather illustrate than confirm the matter, and cannot sustain the rigor of strict disputation; we shall uphold our faith with those two pillars which Christ indicated to us, Matthew 22:29, when He called back the Sadducees, who denied the resurrection, to the Scriptures and the power of God, revealing that ignorance of these things was the source of their error; contrariwise, He laid two foundations for faith in this article, the knowledge of divine will from Scripture, and of divine power from His nature. For since the resurrection of the dead is a divine act, and every act hath two necessary and sufficient principles, namely will and ability, these must also be regarded in this work of resurrection. For these two, conjoined in God, in whom there is no weakness, bring the matter to pass, because our Lord in heaven, whatsoever He willed, He hath done, Psalm 115:3. We have as author the very Son of God, who, from the words of the covenant, I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, Exodus 3:6, which remaineth even after the separation of soul and body, concludeth, against the error of the Sadducees, that there is a resurrection of the dead, because God is not the God of the dead, but of the living, Matthew 22:23, Mark 12:26, Luke 20:38. The saying of Job, chapter 19:25, was judged by Jerome, writing to Pammachius, so clear in this matter that he thought none spoke so plainly of the resurrection after Christ as Job did before Christ.

SPANH. There are clear places in Holy Scripture wherein the future resurrection is declared by God, such as Daniel 12:2, John 5:28, 1 Corinthians 15, 1 Thessalonians 4:14. By these and other such places, either the truth must be abrogated, or the resurrection of the flesh, strictly so called, and distinguished from the spiritual resurrection, of which Paul treateth in Romans 6:5 and Colossians 3:1, must be admitted.

XII. All Men Shall Rise, Even the Wicked.

BUCAN. All men, of every sex and age, who from the creation of the world until its end have died, both the godly and the ungodly, shall rise, but with unequal lot, John 5:28, Matthew 25:32, Acts 24:15. Whence ariseth a twofold resurrection: one called the resurrection of life, which eternal life shall follow, as thou mightest say, vital; the other of judgment or condemnation, that is, damnatory, Daniel 12:2. And because those are truly deemed to rise who rise to eternal life, they are peculiarly called sons of the resurrection, Luke 20:36, though it be established that the wicked shall also rise, to receive eternal destruction, which is not called life, but death, because such an unhappy life ought not properly to be called life.

PROF. The followers of Socinus speak ambiguously of the resurrection of the wicked, saying that it ought rather to be ascribed to Holy Scripture than to their own opinion, if any conclude that the wicked shall not live eternally, because it is drawn from the innermost parts of sacred letters that only the godly shall live forever, which comforteth the faithful with the promise of life alone. Smalcius, page 405, in his refutation of Franzius’s Theses, also saith, page 415, that the wicked shall be immortal, namely in eternal reproach, and that nowhere do the sacred letters approve this, nor can anything be brought from them whereby that opinion may be proved. He had said before that he and his followers never openly proposed this matter. Namely, as they speak elsewhere, sometimes certain things may be said that indicate this opinion to men, until at length the age ripeneth, and men grow accustomed to these ways of speaking.
