But whatever they think or indicate with words, it is certain that the opinion which denieth the resurrection of the wicked and their perpetual duration, by the same stroke abolisheth the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his angels, Matthew 25:41, the unquenchable fire, Matthew 3:12, the worm of the wicked that dieth not, Mark 9:43. For they cannot be afflicted with eternal punishment who do not endure eternally. To what is brought against this, it must be noted in general that, as the name of life, though indifferent to any life, good or evil, blessed or miserable, is sometimes taken strictly to signify a commodious, blessed, and desirable life, as when the Poet saith, It is not living, but being well, that is life; so also in the Creed we say, We believe in eternal life: thus resurrection in sacred authors is often understood only in a good sense, to signify that whereby one riseth to a blessed life. Moreover, resurrection is properly said to be of life when death is truly overcome, succeeded by a life preferable to death; such is not the resurrection of the wicked, whose souls receive their bodies for this, that they may be more grievously punished, and to whom it were better not to rise than to rise to such a state. Hence it cometh that Scripture speaketh of the wicked as if they were never to be recalled to life, meaning that blessed and desirable life.

MACC. Socinus opposeth us here, denying, though somewhat obscurely, that the reprobate shall either rise or be afflicted with eternal torments, and we shall presently bring forth his arguments, now about to prove our opinion. That the reprobate shall be raised and tormented with eternal punishments, these and other places show: John 5:28-29, where Christ expressly teacheth that some shall come forth from the tombs to the resurrection of condemnation. The same is expressly affirmed in Daniel 12:2, where the Holy Spirit saith, Many of them that sleep in the dust of the earth shall awake, some to everlasting life, and some to everlasting contempt. Nor doth it hinder that it is said many, (by which alone some are led to think this place treateth not of the resurrection properly so called), for not all men shall rise, since there shall be those found alive at the Lord’s coming, 1 Corinthians 15:51. That the reprobate shall rise and be subjected to eternal punishments, the process of the final judgment teacheth, Matthew 25:41, and the same is proposed by John the Baptist, Matthew 3:12. And surely, if the reprobate were not to rise, those places which treat of the comparison of the state of the reprobate, that some shall be worse, some more tolerable, could in no wise be explained; for if none were to rise, if all were to be annihilated, none would suffer more evil than another; yet the sacred letters treat of this comparison, see Matthew 11:21, and 25:41. Of Judas the traitor also Christ saith, Matthew 26:24, that it were good for that man if he had never been born, which would rest on no foundation if the reprobate were annihilated at death and were not to rise nor endure infernal punishments; for it would be the same with them after death as if they had never been born. Many other things could be brought to confirm this thesis, but since it is clearly proposed in Scripture, we forbear to bring more, lest we seem to carry light to the sun. Yet one thing we could not pass by, which the Holy Spirit proposeth in 1 Corinthians 15:32: If the dead rise not, let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die. Hence He showeth that from this doctrine, if there be no resurrection, a way is opened to Sardanapalian excess, which I marvel our adversaries do not perceive. Let us now come to their arguments. I find two principal ones in Socinus’s books:

I. That which he taketh from 1 Corinthians 15:22, where it is established that as all die in Adam, so all shall be made alive in Christ; from this he would conclude that as the reprobate are not made alive in Christ, so they shall not rise; for none shall rise unless he be first made alive. But we say that this place treateth not of any resurrection or any vivification, but of the resurrection to life, and of vivification to eternal life. For there is a twofold resurrection, as aforesaid, and each hath diverse causes. For the faithful shall rise by the benefit, power, and efficacy of Christ’s resurrection, which is always salutary and communicated only to His members, Romans 6:8. But the reprobate, by the necessity and efficacy of that divine decree which is in Genesis 2:17, Thou shalt surely die: which decree comprehendeth both deaths, and especially the second and eternal death, it is necessary that the unbelieving also rise, but to greater condemnation, that they may suffer eternal punishments in their bodies also, because it would be a light punishment to be consumed by the first death, since the loss of an infinite good requireth an infinite punishment. Nor doth it hinder that in the said place it is said, All shall be made alive in Christ, as all died in Adam, for the apodosis doth not always correspond to the protasis in the breadth of the object, as may be seen in Romans 5:29; nor because it is said that all are made alive, doth it follow that none are made alive except those in Christ, but only that those who are made alive to eternal life are made alive in Christ. For that the reprobate shall be made alive and rise from another cause, we have already shown.

II. The other objection of Socinus, whereby he insinuates that the reprobate shall not rise and therefore shall not suffer eternal punishments, is this: that their souls after death do not in any wise survive. For if they survived, they would return to God, for of all men who die, whose souls seem to survive (in the manner Socinus understandeth), it is said in Ecclesiastes 12:7, The dust returneth to the earth as it was, and the spirit returneth to God who gave it. Now it would be absurd that the souls of the wicked should return to God, for there would be no difference between the state of the godly and the wicked after this life, which yet Socinus contendeth is asserted by us. Cartwright excellently respondeth to this in his commentary on Ecclesiastes: And if any should say, Well then, it shall go well with us, since our souls shall migrate to God, this opinion seemeth to favor those who affirm that all shall be saved, because all are created by God. Therefore, understand this return, not to the seat of the blessed, but to God as Judge, who, according to deeds done in the body, shall adjudge it either to the pit of hell or to the banquet of heaven. Now the cause that moveth Socinus to this opinion must be brought forth, and it is this: that he denieth God to be infinite in His essence. For if this were so, then surely the reprobate could not be punished with punishments enduring infinitely; for whence would this infinity of punishments arise? From sin? But this is finite in itself, for there cannot be an infinite evil, since all evil is subjectively in good and effectively from good. Or from the fact that the object against which the sin is committed is infinite? And this Socinus hath already denied. Therefore, from his opinion, the reprobate are not to be subjected to eternal punishments, contrary to what the whole sacred Scripture teacheth.

XIII. And All Shall Rise in the Same Bodies.

PROF. We say that the body to rise is the same in number and substance, as is sufficiently clear from the places of Scripture cited above. For this corruptible must put on incorruption, τὸ φθαρτὸν τοῦτο, and this mortal, τὸ θνητὸν τοῦτο, must put on immortality, 1 Corinthians 15:53, and Philippians 3:21, Christ shall transfigure this very body of our humiliation, τὸ σῶμα τῆς ταπεινώσεως, etc. Therefore, the resurrection shall be, that ἕκαστος τὰ ἴδια σώματα, each may receive in the body, or (as the Complutensian edition readeth, 2 Corinthians 5:10), ἴδια σώματα, the proper things of the body, according to what he hath done, whether good or evil, which ought not to be done in another body than that by which each wrought good or evil. Christ also, who is the pattern of our resurrection, rose not in another body than that in which He was affixed to the cross, and in which, even after death, the marks of the nails appeared: Conformed to His body, etc., Philippians 3:21. This also the justice of God requireth, that in the very body in which one obeyed God or sinned, he be rewarded with gifts or afflicted with punishments: nor should one fight and another be crowned; one sin and another be punished. This rather is the series of justice (as Ambrose well saith, Sermon on Faith and Resurrection, chapter 19), that since the act is common to body and soul, what the soul devised, the body effected, both should come to judgment, both be given to punishment or reserved for glory. Nor would it be fitting if the bodies which in the way were made members of Christ should be excluded from the homeland, others being substituted in their place. Resurrection also would not truly be resurrection, but rather a new creation: nor would the condition be the same for the dead and those whom the last day findeth alive. For these, in that transformation, shall not receive other bodies in substance. Add that death in Scripture is called sleep and slumber, but resurrection an awakening, that we may understand the resurrection of the same body in number. Therefore, the flesh shall rise, and indeed all of it, and indeed the same, and indeed entire, Tertullian, On the Resurrection of the Flesh, chapter 63. These things duly considered, it followeth that the error of those is pernicious who either formerly denied, or even in this time deny, the resurrection of the same bodies in number with which we are clothed in this age, which they rather thought, or even now think, ought to be done in airy bodies, or bodies subtler than air, not consisting of flesh and members. Which error some formerly attributed to Origen, though others sought to absolve and purge him from all error concerning the resurrection. Whatever the case, it is certain that many Anabaptists in this time are entangled in this, and Socinus with his followers deny the resurrection of this flesh, who therefore call into doubt those words of the Creed, I believe in the resurrection of the flesh, saying they are not of such authority that they ought to be believed against the testimonies of Scripture. But we show that the same is clearly contained in Scripture. It is to be noted by the way that an error crept into the edition of Calvin’s Epistles in folio, 1576, page 84, where an epistle falsely inscribed Farel to Calvin not only deceived Feuardentius, who petulantly attacketh Calvin on that account, but also the learned Vossius, who in his theses on the resurrection thought that epistle was Farel’s, instructing Calvin on this matter, when it is manifestly Calvin’s to Laelius Socinus, who had raised that dispute, and who on that account is most learnedly refuted by Calvin.

It is false that they say these bodies we carry about shall not rise, but others shall be given to us, as the Apostle teacheth us. For what Paul saith, 1 Corinthians 15:50, Flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God, ought not to be taken as if the resurrected bodies shall lack flesh and blood, for, as Tertullian aptly saith in his book On the Resurrection of the Flesh, Flesh and blood by the name of fault, not of substance, are excluded from the kingdom of God. And by reason of corruption, not of nature, as is clear from what followeth: Nor doth corruption inherit incorruption. But that flesh and blood can be without corruption is clear from this, that the Holy One of God, who had flesh and bones after the resurrection, had not a mortal and corruptible body, such as Adam’s was after the fall, and such as we bear in this life, but an immortal and incorruptible, yea, even spiritual body, not converted into spirit, but distinguished from the animal body which must be sustained by food; spiritual, therefore, because it shall need no food, but the presence of the spirit shall suffice for its life, and also because of other qualities and gifts of the glorious body. No less erroneous is the opinion of Durandus of Saint-Pourçain, who thought that for the resurrection of the same man, the identity of the form in any matter sufficeth, because from the identity of the form, he saith, followeth the identity of merit, since matter hath no actuality of itself, but receiveth its being from the form. And so, though the soul of Peter should take up the body that was Paul’s, and contrariwise, nevertheless the same Peter would rise, and the same Paul, because it is made the same by the same form, in Sentences, Book 4, distinction 44, question 3, which opinion Albertus interpolated in his oration on the resurrection, where he disputeth that men shall rise composed of the four elements as from new matter, so that there is identity not in matter, but in form, etc. For it is false that the numerical identity of a man is contained only in the identity of the soul and the identity of bare prime matter, because for that identity, the same soul, the same human body, and the same flesh and bones are necessary, which also require the same dispositions of prime matter to the soul, by which it hath a peculiar disposition toward this soul, informing this body, and so this matter becometh secondary and designated to this form. For unless those ultimate dispositions were produced, and so the same body, it would not be the same man, since this man substantially consisteth of this soul and this body, and these flesh and bones, which do not exist without these ultimate dispositions; otherwise, in the migration of souls from one body to another, which the Pythagorean Philosophers feigned, and which was also believed among the Jews, there would have been a true resurrection of the same men; since in that μετεμψύχωσις the same soul of the man previously dead would remain, and the same prime matter would be everywhere, of whatsoever bodies. And surely, if the identity of the soul is required for the identity of the man, by the same reason the identity of the body is required, since man consisteth not only of the soul, but of the soul united to the body.

MACC. The Socinians think that we shall not be raised from the dead endowed with that composition and delineation of members which we have in this life, but that God shall form new spiritual bodies, which is false, as is shown from this, that the Apostle teacheth, 1 Corinthians 15, that this mortal must put on immortality: therefore, the subject must necessarily be the same. But the accidental form of the subject shall be different, otherwise there is nothing that putteth on immortality, nor that putteth off the mortal condition.

PROF. Questions concerning infants who die in their mothers’ wombs, aborted fetuses, monsters, and the like, may be conveniently resolved by positing the hypothesis of animation. For either the bodies were truly animated with a human soul, or they were not animated. If the former, resurrection also pertaineth to them; if the latter, such are rightly excluded from resurrection, which do not attain the definition of man. Yet with Augustine we think that those things which are defective shall rise in such wise that their nature is corrected and amended. And all things which, in particular births, whether by having too much or too little, or by some excessive deformity are called monsters, shall by resurrection be recalled to the form of human nature, Enchiridion to Laurentius, chapter 87. With the same we do not hesitate to assert that there shall be a distinction of sexes in the resurrection. Which is rightly inferred from this, that Christ, when asked whose wife the woman should be who had seven brothers as husbands, did not deny that there should be women in the resurrection, which would have been a compendious answer if it were true, but only denied that there should be marriages: yea, He also affirmed that the female sex should be, saying, They neither marry, which pertaineth to women, nor are given in marriage, which pertaineth to men. Therefore, those who here are wont to marry shall be, and those who here are wont to take wives shall be, but they shall not do so there, City of God, Book 22, chapter 17. This followeth also from this, that the same body in number, as was proved above, must rise, which would not be if it had not the same individuating conditions, to which may be added, that in the resurrection, not the individual nature, nor the perfection or integrity of species, but only the defects of nature shall be abolished, among which the distinction of sexes is not to be reckoned. It is also queried concerning all deformities of bodies, from the lack of a fitting member or due quantity, or from the addition of an unfitting member, or from the uncomely situation of members, whether all these shall be corrected? Which questions, as those pertaining to the stature of men, since they have no express solution in Holy Scripture, are resolved only by probable conjectures, which some bring one way, others another; therefore, we think nothing certain can be defined concerning them, only we judge it true that God shall take away from the glorified bodies, of whatsoever sex or stature, whatever might affix any deformity to them. But as for the wicked, the uncertain condition of those whose damnation is certain and eternal ought not to trouble us, Augustine, Enchiridion, chapter 92.

BUCAN. The bodies which are quickened by a human soul, and in this animal and frail life are sustained by external aids, as food and other means created by God, Genesis 1:29, shall become spiritual, not in essence, but in condition or quality, and by participation in the gifts of the Spirit. I. Because they shall be fully governed by the Holy Spirit. II. Because they shall wholly yield themselves to the command of the same Spirit. III. Because, supported by divine power, they shall need no food nor other supports, because they shall be endowed with an exquisite, subtle, and acute perception of the senses. It is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body.

XIV. But Those Found Alive on the Last Day, as They Shall Not Properly Die, So Neither Shall They Rise, but Shall Undergo Something Analogous, That Is, They Shall Be Changed.

PROF. The last day shall find all men in general, either still living or dead. Concerning those who are found alive, it may be asked whether they shall rise, since they have not fallen? For since Christ is said to be appointed by God the judge of the living and the dead, Acts 10:42, if all truly died, the distinction would seem useless. Which distinction the Apostle seemeth to intimate, 1 Corinthians 15:51, 1 Thessalonians 4:14, that (as Tertullian speaketh, On the Resurrection of the Flesh, chapter 41) by a compendium of death through transformation, those who are then found alive, not to die, but to put off mortality and put on immortality ἀτόμῳ, ἐν ῥιπῇ ὀφθαλμοῦ, in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, shall meet with those who rise. For though the place of the Apostle in 1 Corinthians 15, which chiefly proveth this, is variously read in Greek and Latin codices; yet the collation of the other in 1 Thessalonians 4 hardly suffereth it to be taken otherwise than as the Greeks took it, to which also the words most fitly agree, which the Apostle prefaced, Behold, I show you a mystery; to which an inferential discourse, πάντες μὲν κοιμηθησόμεθα, we shall all indeed sleep, would not fit, which reading is justly suspected by William Estius, Professor of Douai, writing on this place. Therefore, the usual reading of the Greeks seemeth truer, πάντες μὲν οὐκοιμηθησόμεθα, πάντες δὲ ἀλλαγησόμεθα, we shall not all sleep, but we shall all be changed, notwithstanding the objections of Catharinus and Stapleton, who contend that the place is corrupted, and the latter ascribeth an impious sense to it. But by no means, saith Estius, is the reading of the Greek codices improbable, yea, in many ways more probable, so far is it from being accused of temerity and presumption, as Catharinus accuseth in his commentary, who himself ought to be condemned for inconsiderate judgment in this matter. From this reading, all the Greeks we have, ancient as they are, deduce that not all men shall die, and therefore not properly rise: to which opinion some Latins also, as Tertullian, On the Resurrection of the Flesh, chapters 41-42, Jerome, Epistle to Marcella, inclined. In which there is no danger, Estius confesseth. Augustine, as his custom is in matters not plainly settled, speaketh modestly: Either they shall not die, or from this life to death, and from death to eternal life, by a most swift transformation, as in the twinkling of an eye, they shall not feel death, Retractations, Book 2, chapter 33. The author of the book On Ecclesiastical Dogmas, chapter 7, saith: Since there are other equally Catholic and learned men who believe that those found alive at the coming of the Lord shall be changed to incorruption and immortality while the soul remaineth in the body; and this is reputed to them for resurrection from the dead, that they put off mortality by transformation, not by death: whichever way one acquiesceth, he is not a heretic. We also judge that neither opinion is to be condemned, provided that those who commonly hold in the law of the Church that it sufficeth to believe in the future resurrection of the flesh from death.

XV. Christ Shall Judge All.

PROF. In the foundations of Christian doctrine, according to the Apostle, Hebrews 6:2, these two are conjoined: the resurrection of the dead and eternal judgment. And among other arguments for the resurrection, not the least was taken from the justice of God, which requireth that all be presented before the tribunal of Christ, 2 Corinthians 5:10. Of that judgment, therefore, we must consequently speak, but briefly, because most of its circumstances we have touched upon in the connected matter of the resurrection. By judgment we understand, not the particular judgment which God exerciseth in this life or at the death of each man, which may be called precedent, partial, and hidden; but the universal, final, total, eternal, and manifest judgment, which shall be instituted on the last day after the universal resurrection: which Jude, verse 6, calleth κρίσιν μεγάλης ἡμέρας, the judgment of the great day; 2 Peter 3:12, ἡμέραν Θεοῦ, the day of God; Paul, Romans 2:5, with respect to the reprobate, ἡμέραν ὀργῆς, the day of wrath; and Ephesians 4:30, with respect to the godly, ἡμέραν ἀπολυτρώσεως, the day of redemption; as Acts 3:20 calleth it the time of ἀναψύξεως, refreshing, and verse 21, ἀποκαταστάσεως πάντων, the restitution of all things. The matter or object of the final judgment, if we regard persons, are all evil angels and all men, both good and evil. For though the demons have been subject to punishments from the very moment of their fall, and adjudged to eternal damnation; and whithersoever they go, they always carry their hell with them: yet God hath cast them into Tartarus, delivered to chains of darkness, εἰς κρίσιν τετηρημένους, reserved for judgment, 2 Peter 2:4, Jude 6; we doubt not that on that day they shall receive the complement and fullness of their punishments, when they can no longer harm men, extort divine worship from their slaves, being so confined to the infernal prison that no exit remaineth open to them. To this must be referred what the Apostle saith, 1 Corinthians 6:3, Know ye not that we shall judge angels? which is to be understood in the Head, Christ. As for men, of whom we ought especially to be solicitous in this question, all shall be judged, the greatest and the least, none excepted, but the good by a judgment of discretion only; the evil by a judgment of condemnation. For we shall all stand before the judgment seat of Christ, 2 Corinthians 5:10. The great and the small John expressly distinguisheth, Revelation 20:12. And among those to be judged, he comprehendeth both, that none be excepted. Likewise the living and the dead, Acts 10:42. Nor are the saints excepted. There is laid up for me a crown of righteousness, which the Lord shall render to me in that day, 2 Timothy 4:8. The same time is assigned for giving reward to God’s servants and for destroying those who destroy the earth, Revelation 11:18. Therefore, if it be said that believers shall not be judged or come into judgment, it must be understood of condemnation. If the wicked shall not rise in judgment, it must be referred to subsistence in judgment, because their cause shall fall. To the object of that judgment pertain also all the acts of all men, both good and evil, under which are comprehended words and thoughts: the manifestation of all which shall be in the day of judgment, denoted by the opening of the books, Revelation 20:12. Then for every idle word that men shall speak, they shall give account in the day of judgment, Matthew 12:36. For good acts shall be approved and rewarded with gratuitous remuneration; but evil acts shall be disapproved and judged worthy of punishment.

AMES. The sins of the faithful shall not come into judgment: for since in this life they are covered and taken away by the sentence of justification, and that final judgment shall be a confirmation and manifestation of the same sentence, it would not be consonant that they should then be brought to light again.

MACC. The judge shall be Christ, Matthew 25:31, as to the visible judicial act; but the whole undivided Trinity, as to consent and authority. Christ shall judge according to both natures, but preserving the properties of each: for to know and produce all the secrets of men is of the Deity; to pronounce sentence is also of the human nature. The effective power, whether to life or to death, is again of the Deity. Thus Christ shall judge the world by the action of His Deity and humanity, though the parts of the humanity shall not be the same as those of the Deity in judgment.

XVI. The Parts of the Judgment Are the Pronouncement of Sentence and Its Execution.

MACC. The final judgment hath two parts: the judicial process and the execution. The judicial process is both the separation of the elect from the reprobate and the pronouncement of the sentence. The separation is in some sort begun in this life, but shall not be perfected until the end of the world. How pleasing this shall be to the godly may easily be gathered from the parable of the tares, Matthew 13. Likewise, 2 Thessalonians 2:1. It shall be a matter of great joy to the godly to behold one another gathered together to go to the heavenly inheritance: but of incomparable felicity to behold the glory of Christ, in whom they hoped and to whom they commended themselves for their salvation. But this separation from the reprobate shall be when the elect, compelled by angels from all parts of the world, shall be set on Christ’s right hand, the reprobate on His left. This judgment shall begin with the godly, Matthew 25, and that because, absolved by Christ’s solemn and clear sentence, they may afterward be judges of the wicked, both angels and men. The pronouncement of the sentence shall begin with the godly, the execution with the wicked, both that the godly may with their eyes behold their vindication (as it is in Psalm 58:10 and 78:10), and that by comparison with the misery of the wicked they may more fully acknowledge their own felicity. The pronouncement of the sentence shall be that whereby Christ shall do justice to all and assign to each according to their works, Matthew 25, 1 Corinthians 4:5, Revelation 20:12 and 18.

SPANH. The form of this judgment consisteth partly in the cognition of the cause, partly in its decision and the pronouncement of the peremptory sentence, partly in the execution thereof, all which are represented in that judicial process which is instituted, Matthew 25.

XVII. The Time and Place of the Judgment, as Regards Those to Be Judged, Are Equally Uncertain.

PROF. A special place wherein the godly and the wicked shall be gathered cannot be determined from Holy Scripture. For what the Jews, followed by the Papists, fable about the valley of Jehoshaphat resteth on no solid foundation. But what is cited from Joel 3:2 and 12, I will gather all nations and bring them down into the valley of Jehoshaphat, is to be understood figuratively; unless one prefer to take the valley of Jehoshaphat, that is, the judgment of God, appellatively for every place in which God shall judge, which in the same chapter is called the valley of decision. As for the time, we strive in vain to compute and define the years that remain to this age; since we hear from the mouth of truth that it is not ours to know, as Augustine well admonisheth, City of God, Book 18, chapter 53, considering that Christ expressly forbade that inquiry, Acts 1:7. And the Apostle, taught in Paradise, thought it not at all necessary to write of the times and seasons of the Lord’s coming, 1 Corinthians 5:1. Since, therefore, the determined place and the definite time lie hidden in the treasures of divine wisdom, it would be rash to inquire of them; and those who presume to foretell the time have often been convicted of temerity by the contrary event, by God, who willed that one day be hidden, that all might be watched, lest men sleep on the pillow of security.

XVIII. Now Also This World Shall Perish, Not by Total Annihilation, but by Transformation for the Better.

WAL. The manner whereby the world shall perish is by fire, 2 Peter 3:7, The heavens and the earth which now are, by the same word are kept in store, reserved unto fire, etc. So 2 Thessalonians 1:7, The Lord Jesus shall be revealed from heaven with His mighty angels in flaming fire. And Isaiah 66:15 had foretold it before: Behold, the Lord will come with fire, etc. These seem sufficiently explained. But it is queried whether the whole world shall perish? Certainly, it cannot be said of heaven, the seat of the blessed, because Scripture calleth eternal life a substance abiding in the heavens, Hebrews 10:34; likewise a dwelling not made with hands, and eternal, 2 Corinthians 5:1; and what is visible is said to be temporal, but τὰ ἀόρατα, the invisible, eternal, 2 Corinthians 4:18. Likewise, Matthew 25:34, Therefore it shall not be prepared at the end of the age. Of hell, or that place prepared for the devil and his angels, it is the common opinion that it shall not perish, because Christ shall not create a new one on that day, but shall cast them into the fire which was already prepared for the devil, Luke 16:26, where it is said, χάσμα ἐστήρικται, a gulf is fixed. Jude 13, The mist of darkness is reserved for them forever, and passim in Revelation, the wicked are cast into the hell already existing; it is never said that He shall then prepare a new one or renew the old; which those easily defend who place hell outside the visible heaven, but because they place it under the earth, they must necessarily hold that only a part of the earth and sea, not the whole earth, shall perish, but that it shall be condemned to perpetual darkness on one side. Therefore, the principal question is concerning this visible world, whether it shall be wholly reduced to nothing, or only changed according to its qualities? Those who think it shall wholly perish rely on not ineffectual arguments.

I. Because Scripture calleth it τέλος, ἀποτέλεσμα, the end and consummation of the age; likewise φθορά, the destruction of the world: it useth the figure of a book rolled up and cast into the fire; likewise of an old garment which is cast away, and a new one substituted from other matter, Hebrews 1:10, from Psalm 102:26.

II. The place in 2 Peter 3:10 is urged, in which the heavens are said to pass away with a great noise, and the elements to be dissolved with fervent heat, etc.

III. Especially, various places from Revelation are brought, which seem to denote all manner of destruction: as the angel sweareth by Him who liveth forever that there shall be time no longer, Revelation 10:6. Therefore, neither the subject of time. Likewise, Revelation 20:11 and 21:1 and 23.

On the contrary, the following arguments are usually brought.

I. Because the destruction shall be by fire; therefore, it shall not wholly consume, but purge: for fire requireth some subject.

II. Because elsewhere Scripture explaineth it by transformation, as Psalm 102:26; likewise by palingenesia, regeneration, Matthew 22:30. But regeneration is only the ingeneration of new qualities. So Paul, 1 Corinthians 7:31, saith the schema, the fashion of this world, passeth away; and Peter, 2 Peter 3:6, compareth this destruction of the world with the destruction by the flood.

III. The most efficacious place is Romans 8:19, where the Apostle saith that the creature, as it were with outstretched neck, observeth and expecteth the revelation of the sons of God, and addeth the cause: For the creature was made subject to vanity, etc. Which place necessarily proveth that the creature shall not be wholly abolished, but vindicated and delivered, and that συνωδίνειν and συστενάζειν must be understood of a natural appetite. For that some would understand angels by the creature is absurd, because they are not subject to vanity and the bondage of corruption. Nor can it be understood of the godly indefinitely, because it saith πᾶσα κτίσις, all creation. Nor of the wicked, because they have not this hope, nor are unwillingly, but willingly and spontaneously subject to their sins. Therefore, that opinion seemeth best to reconcile these places, which, from the place of Peter cited before, and especially from the latter words of verse 12, establisheth that these visible heavens, together with the subject elements, shall by fire, like some metal, be resolved into a liquid and immense pool; but the earth and terrestrial bodies shall by the same fire be resolved into ashes, whence shall arise a confused mass of immense bulk, from which God shall create new heavens and a new earth.

Thus, this heaven shall pass away and flee, and be changed and renewed.

SOHN. Again, this transformation shall be not by waters, as in the flood, but by fire divinely kindled. That this world shall not be destroyed by waters, God Himself testifieth, Genesis 9, and willed the rainbow to be a sign of this. That this world shall be destroyed by fire, Peter teacheth, 2 Peter 3:7 and 12. Likewise, Paul teacheth, 2 Thessalonians 1:8. The renewal or restoration of the world is that whereby God shall introduce a new external form or new incorruptible qualities, Revelation 21, Romans 8:20, Isaiah 65. Though what this restoration shall be cannot be distinctly said, because it is not revealed in Scripture.

SPANH. The first opinion, of a total transformation of the world, hath great authors, and is laboriously proved by many, partly by inartificial arguments from divine or human authority, partly by artificial arguments from reason. The second opinion, of a partial transformation of the world, pleaseth also great men, who oppose authorities with authorities, reasons with reasons. To us, a middle and moderate division of this question seemeth safest, namely, that neither of these opposed opinions is to be deemed impious or absurd, and that a suspension of judgment concerning both is lawful, yet the latter seemeth to us more probable, by the argument of the place drawn from Romans 8:19-21, etc., which promiseth not the annihilation, but the restoration of the creature (κτίσις), by which neither the intellectual nor rational can be understood.

MACC. The former argue thus: What would be the use of this renewal is not easily perceived. For since this visible world was created for man’s sake, when he ceaseth to use it, it followeth that it is in vain. But by so reasoning, they openly contradict the Apostle’s mind and scope. For the Apostle teacheth that the world or creature is subject to vanity, not of its own accord, that is, not because it brought this evil upon itself, but because of man, who subjected it to vanity by sinning. But to what end doth the Apostle teach this? Namely, to show that, sin being abolished and man fully restored, the creature also shall be restored. For if either the creature were reduced to nothing, or remained indeed, but foul and deformed, there would remain a vestige of sin and death, yea, a monument. But the creature restored is raised as a trophy of the sons of God. So princes, if they destroy the fortresses and castles of rebellious subjects, even if nothing returneth from them, yet when fully reconciled with their subjects, they often restore those fortresses and castles. What shall be the use of the renewed creature? This, namely, that it be an argument of sin wholly destroyed. Then it seemeth utterly absurd that to so many plants, so many herbs, which have already perished, and to so many brute animals, not only life should be restored, but immortality. But this ought not greatly to move us. For as if any should ask us what shall be the glorious state and condition of our bodies in the blessed resurrection, and demand whether all parts of the body, internal and external, shall be fully restored? And then ask what shall be the use of each part? Such curiosity, I might almost say impious, must be refuted, that we commit this whole matter to God (who well knoweth what is expedient, what less expedient, for conferring glory and dignity on our bodies, which are now so vile and abject), being little solicitous about those jejune and thorny questions. We must now come to the others, who for themselves bring these words of divine oracles from Isaiah 65: Behold, I will create new heavens and a new earth, and the former shall not be remembered, nor come into mind. Response: Creation in sacred letters is sometimes taken for a change of qualities, or an extraordinary and divine alteration, as Psalm 51, Create in me a clean heart, O God. Secondly, the place is allegorical, and its sense is that Jehovah shall restore all things in Christ. See the text.

XIX. The Blessed Shall Be Taken Up into the Heavens, Perfectly and Eternally Glorified in Body and Soul.

BUCAN. Eternal life is a glorious state, in which the elect, after the future resurrection of the dead, fully joined to Christ their Head, shall in the heavens with the angels, in a manner now unknown to us and incomprehensible, enjoy God’s presence, and eternally celebrate Him, attaining the chief good obtained for us by Christ, and shall be conformed in body and soul to His image, as man.

XX. But Heavenly Blessedness Consisteth in the Enjoyment or Vision of Divine Glory.

WAL. That this eternal life consisteth in communion with God is taught throughout Scripture; as, Blessed is the people whose God is the Lord, Psalm 33:12, and in the formula of the covenant, Hebrews 8:10. So 1 John 3:2. This communion of men with God is had in two ways, either in this life or in the life to come; in this life begun, in the life to come perfected. Imperfectly in this life through faith; perfectly it shall be had through sight; as the Apostle clearly distinguisheth, 2 Corinthians 5:7, For we walk here by faith, not by sight. All the Schoolmen agree that blessedness is considered either objectively or formally. Our objective blessedness is God, because in Him alone all the conditions of the chief good are found: the first, that all things are referred to His attainment; the second, that He is most perfect; the third, that He is most delightful; the fourth, that He fully satisfieth the appetite. And Scripture clearly indicateth this, as Genesis 15:1, Psalm 33:12, and 148:5. But concerning formal blessedness, or the use and enjoyment of this object, it is queried wherein it consisteth? Since in man the chief part is the soul, and in the soul the intellect and the will, Thomas and Scotus dispute whether formal blessedness is an act of the intellect or of the will. Thomas holdeth it to be an act of the intellect; Scotus, of the will. For we enjoy God in both ways, both by the act of the intellect apprehending Him, and by the act of the will loving Him and resting in Him apprehended. For that pleasure is nothing else but the rest of the mind, or rather the acquiescence in the good obtained. And that all these three are required in true blessedness is beyond controversy. But though it is not necessary to institute a comparison, yet we acknowledge that Thomas’s opinion is rightly defended by most, not only because the intellect is man’s most excellent faculty, and because the action of the intellect first apprehendeth the object of blessedness and maketh itself more like to what it apprehendeth; but the action of the will is a certain fruit thereof, whether we consider charity bearing itself toward the object, or that joy or acquiescence: but also because Holy Scripture almost setteth the vision of God as the foundation of this blessedness. Of many places, let these be considered, Psalm 16:11 and 17:15, Matthew 5:8, 1 Corinthians 13:12, 1 John 3:2. From which places it appeareth that the very vision of God is promised, not only as formal blessedness, but also as the foundation and cause of all other things in blessedness and eternal life.

MACC. It is queried whether in the life to come the human mind can rise so far as to comprehend God perfectly, since to comprehend God in this life exceedeth the measure of our thought? For all imperfection shall be abolished in the life to come. But it is an imperfection not to be able to comprehend God, otherwise to have comprehended God would be no perfection: therefore, it seemeth that in the life to come, in which only perfection hath place, we shall perfectly comprehend God. But the essential imperfection of the creature (which imperfection is not said comparatively to creatures, but with respect to God), which imperfection is only a negation of supreme perfection, that is, it only importeth that the creature is not God: if that imperfection were removed, it would follow that we should be gods, which would be absurd and blasphemous to think or say. Yet privative imperfection, which noteth some defect in the creature when compared with itself, that is, when we think the creature is not as perfect as it can be while remaining a creature, all such imperfection shall be abolished; for example, whatever can perfect the body, so that the body ceaseth not to be a body (for perfection doth not destroy the subject, but adorneth it): whatever can perfect the soul, so that the soul ceaseth not to be a soul, that shall be present in the life to come. Therefore, it remaineth to be asked whether it pertaineth to the perfection of the soul that we comprehend the essence of God? Response: It seemeth not, and the reason is that the incomprehensible cannot be comprehended. But they say, Though the infinite cannot be comprehended distinctly, yet it can be comprehended confusedly, and this comprehension they called, whence that celebrated saying: God is known wholly, but not totally, and they bring the example of the eyes, which behold the whole man, confusedly indeed, but not totally. Response: The comparison is not the same between things that fall under the sense of the eyes and the divinity; for sensible things are composite, therefore they cannot be wholly comprehended by any sense, but the Deity is most simple, surely neither the mind, much less the senses, can confusedly comprehend things that are most simple, unless it comprehend them otherwise than by essence; that is, by apprehending the very essence. Therefore, if God is known by us by essence, it is necessary that He be known by us distinctly: and if He is known distinctly by us, He is also comprehended; which those who hold that God is seen in the life to come by essence are unwilling to concede. Yet they lack not arguments. For first they say that man’s happiness is placed in union with God: but there would be none unless the intellect see His essence. But nothing can be said more absurd by this argument, for it contradicteth the axiom commonly used in the Schools, Everything received is received according to the mode of the receiver. Now if the essence of God shall be seen, it shall be seen in a finite mode, for the receiver is finite: therefore, the infinite shall be seen by essence in a finite mode, which implieth a contradiction. For finite knowledge is a certain image of the thing in the mind, therefore if the knowledge is finite, but the thing comprehended infinite, it followeth that the thing is known and not known. Secondly, they say: No one shall be happy unless the intellectual happiness be fulfilled: but the intellect shall not be satisfied unless it know the first cause, which cannot be known if it be known through a medium, namely through a species, for no species of the first cause is given. But this reason hath no weight either, unless perchance they mean that the divine essence be wholly comprehended; for it can be said that the appetite of the intellect shall not be fulfilled unless the first cause be wholly comprehended, which they yet deny. But if they respond that there is no appetite of the mind conjoined with reason to seek perfect knowledge of the first cause, we also respond that there is no legitimate appetite of the intellect to seek knowledge of the divine essence, but just as the touch doth not aspire to the essence of fire, but to the effects of fire, and those tempered to the mode of touch: so plainly our mind seeketh only to know of God as much as the mode of the mind requireth; if it tendeth beyond, it is madness. Lastly, they say, 1 John 3:2, We shall see Him as He is. We may respond that that place treateth of Christ, who surely shall be seen by us as He is, namely according to His human nature, for He is not seen by us in this life. But another response more fitting to the Apostle’s scope and the truth of the matter: Whenever mention is made in Scripture of the vision of God, it is not understood as the vision of His essence, but a certain peculiar revelation of divine majesty: as when Jacob, after that famous wrestling, professeth that he hath seen God face to face, Genesis 32:30, he doth not profess that he saw the essence of God, which all agree cannot be seen in this life: And Numbers 12:6-8 testifieth that God addresseth Moses otherwise than the other prophets, namely, that He speaketh to Moses face to face, not so to the other prophets. For all other prophets are terrified and struck by visions of God, and the state of their mind is changed in them, or they do not perceive what they utter: for they are rapt into a certain ecstasy while prophesying, their mind is moved: but to Moses, though the splendor of divine majesty shone around him, no such thing happened, but he stood unmoved. Lastly, Moses testifieth, Deuteronomy 5:5, that God spoke to the people face to face, which cannot be understood otherwise than of a certain peculiar mode of revelation, which hath something eminent and singular above the other modes by which God revealed Himself. Otherwise, when God addresseth Moses, Exodus 33:23, Thou shalt see My back parts, but My face shall no man see and live, this is what Paul said, 1 Corinthians 15:50, Flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God. For in that place the face of God is not the inscrutable essence of God, but that mode of vision which hath place only in the life to come, as if the Lord should say: What I am toward My Church, no man could in this life fully perceive; he must first die and be changed before he can rise to that.Therefore, in this life God is seen, and indeed face to face, but comparatively. For example, Jacob saw God face to face more than others, and Moses more than Jacob. But all vision of God in this life is enigmatic, as Paul teacheth, 1 Corinthians 13 and 2 Corinthians 5:7. Therefore, some will say, in the life to come we shall see God, not in an enigma, and therefore in His essence. Response: God may be considered in two ways; either as He is in Himself, and so God is seen by none, not even by those angels whom they suppose to be of the highest order, namely the Seraphim, who, standing before the majesty of God, cover their eyes with their wings: or God is considered as He is toward us, and so He is perfectly seen in the life to come; in this life only in an enigma. An example of this is a child, who in early infancy knoweth his father, not, I say, the essence of the father, but yet knoweth the father, yet doth not perceive what the father is, not, I say, as to essence, but as to paternal effect, until he is grown and hath experienced and acknowledged how much the father hath done or would do for his sake. Since, therefore, in this life our blessedness cometh to us only in hope, and it is so sublime that it surpasseth our thought, we see not God as He is. Therefore, those see God as He is who in reality and fact experience such goodness of God as a human creature can experience.

Are we in the life to come to see God with bodily eyes? No, because God is not color or bodily light, which alone are the objects of the eyes. But they object that we shall not be raised from the dead endowed with that composition and delineation of members which we have in this life, but that God shall form new spiritual bodies, and therefore we shall also have spiritual eyes, whose objects shall also be spiritual. Response: This is false, as is shown from this, that the Apostle teacheth, 1 Corinthians 15:53, that this mortal must put on immortality. Therefore, the subject must necessarily be the same: but the accidental form of the subject shall be different, otherwise there is nothing that putteth on immortality, nor that putteth off the mortal condition: Therefore, that vision of the body is exploded, of which none ever thought except the Anthropomorphites.

XXI. But the Damned Shall Be Cast into Hell, to Be Punished Eternally.

MACC. Moreover, infernal punishment is not unfitly distinguished into the punishment of loss and the punishment of sense. The punishment of loss is variously described in sacred letters, namely, by being cast out, Luke 13:28; by not entering the holy city Jerusalem, Revelation 21:27; by being outside, Revelation 22:15. This part of infernal punishment admitteth no degrees, for all the reprobate are equally excluded from the kingdom of heaven, not one more, another less. This part of punishments is the greatest, so that the punishment of sense in comparison is almost nothing. For this punishment, namely of sense, noteth a finite evil in nature, though infinite in duration: but the punishment of loss is, as the privation of an infinite good, so the greatest and infinite evil. Hence Chrysostom, Homily to the People of Antioch: Many men fear only hell, but I deem the loss of that glory far greater than hell. If this cannot be proved by discourse, it is no wonder. For we know not the blessedness of the good, that we may clearly know the misery of the evil from their privation: surely Paul, who clearly knew these things, knew that to fall from the glory of Christ is most grievous, and we shall know it when we come to the same experience. And hence it is clear in how great error those are who, foolishly holding that infants dying without baptism, even of the faithful, are excluded from heaven, lest they seem to judge cruelly against them, teach that their punishment is diminished, willing that they shall suffer only the punishment of loss, not of sense.

MART. Some have thought that all men shall be saved, that the benefit of Christ may extend as widely as the harm of Adam. Origen seemeth to have thought this. Yet in sacred letters we have of the punishments of the damned, Their worm shall not be quenched. And Christ is said in the final judgment to cast the damned into eternal fire. But if thou cavil that eternal in sacred letters is sometimes joined to things that last long, and it is not always required that they have no end. Response: This cannot be applied to this question. For those things which, by a trope, on account of their long duration are sometimes called eternal, though they have an end, are proved finite and interrupted by the sacred letters themselves: But if it be not established, we shall always take eternal in its proper signification. And since in sacred Scripture no mention is made of a future change after the sentence of the supreme Judge, as to the condition or state of things, we shall simply take His words: for whatever is assumed is a figment. Nor is it necessary, as they assume, that the benefit of Christ extend as widely as the harm and loss contracted from Adam.

WAL. As we have shown that eternal life properly consisteth in the conjunction of man with God: so eternal death is rightly said to consist in the separation of man from God: whence Scripture calleth it rejection from the face of the Lord and exclusion from the kingdom of Christ. But that the force and form of this death may be more certainly perceived, first of all, against the Socinians and Epicureans, it must be demonstrated that it consisteth not in the eternal abolition of soul and body; which blasphemy is intolerable among Christians.

I. From this, that not only the just, but also the unjust shall rise, Daniel 12:2, John 5:29, Acts 26:23, 2 Corinthians 5:15. But to what end should they rise to abolition, who are already abolished, either fully, according to them, or at least in part and in body?

II. Because it introduceth the mortality of the soul, when Scripture and nature teach the contrary. We grant indeed that God by His omnipotence can reduce the whole world to nothing: but we deny that therefore any souls perish eternally, as the Socinians think of all the wicked.

III. Because sacred Scripture teacheth that eternal death is conjoined with eternal torments and most grievous anguish in soul and body, as may be seen throughout. There shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth, Mark 9:44, Matthew 8:12 and 25:30. But he who is not, feeleth no torment; an example of this is the rich man placed in hell, Luke 16:24. Likewise, the Sodomites, who suffer the punishment of eternal fire, Jude 7.

IV. Christ teacheth that it had been better for some wicked men if they had not been born, as He speaketh of Judas the traitor, Matthew 26:24, Mark 14:21. But to one who is not, and to one not born, the condition is the same.

V. The conscience of the wicked, otherwise fully aware that punishments remain for them, sufficiently showeth: whence they often fall into despair and other crimes.

VI. The damned in the final judgment shall be cast into eternal fire, Matthew 25:41. But the devil and his angels shall not be extinguished in the final judgment, but are reserved in eternal chains, Jude 6.

Another opinion is that of the Origenists and certain Anabaptists of our age, as the Augsburg Confession testifieth, and Bullinger, Book 2, chapter 15, Against the Anabaptists. And certain Papists fable that some already damned in hell have been freed from it by the intercession of certain saints, as they prattle of Trajan, freed by the prayers of Gregory; the same they report of Thecla, who is said to have once freed Falconilla from hell, etc. All these are refuted by the following arguments.

I. Because Scripture expressly calleth it eternal death and reproach, as Daniel 12:2, Matthew 25:41. And there it is opposed to eternal life: The unjust shall go into eternal punishment, but the righteous into eternal life. Therefore, they are said to go into eternal punishment in the same sense that these go into eternal life.

II. This eternity is so described that no exception is shown, as Mark 9:44, Matthew 12:32, Revelation 14:11 and 19:3, Luke 16:26.

III. From the conditions required for the alleviation of punishments, faith and repentance, etc., of which there is no place in hell, as Galatians 6:10, 1 Corinthians 13:8, 2 Corinthians 6:2, Hebrews 3:13, Exhort one another while it is called today, John 9:4. See also the parable of the foolish virgins, Matthew 25:1-13.

IV. Lastly, this was the error of Origen, always condemned by the whole ancient Church.

XXII. Concerning the Place and Fire of Hell, We Ought Not to Be Curiously Solicitous, but Only to Take Heed Diligently and Timely to Avoid It.

PROF. The place destined for those miserable men, as also for the demons, is frequently called in Scripture ᾅδης, that is, hell, also the abyss, Gehenna, the pit of the abyss, and the lake burning with fire and brimstone, that from the very horror of the place the gravity of the punishments may be better gathered; but where the situation of this place is, it is not to be inquired too curiously, but rather the way and means whereby it may be avoided by us: yet meanwhile, as we dare not disapprove the opinion of those who, on account of the common notion of the foregoing names, and because it is often opposed to the highest heaven, and is said to be descended into, place it in the dark caverns of the earth and sea; so we are unwilling to reject the opinion of Chrysostom, Luther, and other more recent men, who think it is constituted outside the visible world, and therefore judge it to be placed outside the heavenly Jerusalem, and designated by the name of outer darkness, Matthew 8:12 and 25:30.

MACC. Now it must be queried concerning the place where the damned shall be, and in which they shall suffer punishments; the question is difficult. Augustine saith: In what part of the world or of things the eternal fire shall be, I think no man knoweth. But he changed or retracted this opinion, Retractations, Book 2, chapter 24, holding that hell is a subterranean place, distinct from heaven, and that the infernal regions are under the earth. To Broughton the Englishman, it is in a region above the world. To others, hell is in the region of the air: To others, in some part of the earth’s surface, as in the Icelandic mountain, of which thus Dr. Peucerus in his book On Divination: There is in Iceland a mountain, Hecla, terrible for the immense depth of its chasm or rather hell, resounding with the miserable and lamentable wailing of those crying, so that the voices of the mourners are heard round about at the distance of a great mile. Around it fly the blackest flocks of crows and vultures, which the inhabitants think nest there. The common people are persuaded that there is a descent through that chasm to the infernal regions, because, as they have learned by long experience, almost whenever battles are fought elsewhere, in whatsoever part of the world, or bloody slaughters occur, horrible tumults are stirred round about, and great cries and wailings are raised.Others deny that Gehenna or hell is a certain place: such are Brentius, Schegkius, and others, as we think, wrongly. For Scripture indicateth it to be a place, Luke 16:26, 1 Peter 3:19-20, likewise in the Epistle of Jude, verse 6. We, with Goclenius, hold that Gehenna or hell is a certain hidden receptacle of the souls of the damned and tormented, as Augustine speaketh: though Gehenna in Scripture is also taken for infernal punishments.

PROF. But whether and how a true and bodily fire shall further afflict them, it is not necessary that we dispute too anxiously with the Schoolmen. Let it suffice us here that the force of their torments shall be so great that it were better for those men not to have been born, Matthew 26:24, and that from the mere fear and apprehension of their pain the wicked are said to bite their tongues and blaspheme the God of heaven, Revelation 16:10. And on the last day they shall in vain say to the mountains and rocks, Fall on us, and hide us from the face of Him that sitteth on the throne, and from the wrath of the Lamb: for the great day of His wrath is come; and who shall be able to stand?

XXIII. Lastly, That There Shall Be Degrees of Glory and of Punishments in the Life to Come Is Not Improbable.

WAL. Whether there be degrees of eternal glory, to define this is not so easy. Certain among the Reformed deny it, as Musculus. And Martyr maketh it only a probable matter. But the well-nigh universal consent of the Christian Church, both Reformed, and also ancient and recent, is to me of greater weight than the doubting of a few. Wherefore:

I. The objective blessedness shall be one and the same for all, namely, God.

II. The essential blessedness also, consisting in those things afore expounded, namely, the vision of God, and our full sanctification and glorification. Yet there may be diversity in the degrees of this glory, and in the clarity of vision, according to the distribution of the illumination bestowed. This is demonstrated:

I. For the Scripture throughout testifieth that God shall render to every man according to his works, as Romans 2:6, 2 Corinthians 5:10.

II. If God in this life adorneth the faithful with divers spiritual gifts, and with divers degrees of gifts, surely it is more than probable, yea, it is certain, that this shall also be in the life to come. The antecedent is certain. Therefore, etc.

III. There are express places that indicate this, as Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob hold the chief place in the kingdom of heaven, Matthew 8:11, Luke 16:22, Lazarus in Abraham’s bosom. Therefore, Abraham reclineth in a higher place. So Matthew 19:28, Christ singularly promiseth twelve thrones, wherein the Apostles shall sit with Christ. For though elsewhere the faithful are said to judge the world, 1 Corinthians 6:3, yet not that order nor this nearness is assigned to them. So also John 14:2, In My Father’s house are many mansions. For that some refer this to the capacity of heaven is not likely, since of that none ever doubted. So Paul, 1 Thessalonians 2:19, saith that they shall be his glory in that day, which cannot be said of all the blessed. So in Revelation 4, to the living creatures and the four-and-twenty elders, expressly distinct places and degrees are assigned in the heavenly Jerusalem. The places of Daniel 12 and 1 Corinthians 15:41, these places, I say, I pass over: for probable responses are offered, though those places may also rightly be applied thereto, when the matter is proved from other places.

IV. From the contrary, namely, the degrees of punishment in hell, which is beyond controversy among all, and is acknowledged by Martyr himself as a very probable argument. So also from the diverse degrees of dignity among the angels, whose like we shall be.

Objection. One place, Matthew 20:12, where all who labor in the vineyard receive equal reward. But this is spoken with respect to those who labored not equally long.

Responses:

I. Blessed immortality is indeed an equal reward, but it followeth not thence that there cannot be other gracious, accidental additions.

II. By this parable, Christ only meaneth to teach that the reward is given not of merit, but of God’s grace and goodness, as it hath seemed good to Him. This is proved hence:

I. For otherwise, those who labored more would murmur, which cannot be in heaven.

II. For those first were the Jews, the last the Gentiles, and it would follow that the godly among the Jews, laboring the whole day, would demand more than a denarius, that is, eternal life, which cannot be.

Second Objection. There shall be no cause why more should be given to one than to another, for it is of Christ’s merit and grace.

Response. Truly, the cause of that diversity in glory shall not be the merits of men, but God’s grace alone, yet proportioned to that measure of grace wherewith each was endowed in this life. For as God hath diversely bestowed His gifts in the way, so also shall He diversely crown them in the homeland.

FINIS.
